4.12.010 Boards, Commissions, And Committees Authorized
The city council hereby authorizes the creation of boards, commissions, and committees to assist the council in carrying out the work of the city in an efficient and cost effective manner. All boards, commissions, or committees are not vested with the authority to make decisions regarding the public's business, but are advisory bodies whose purpose is to research issues, provide information, and make recommendations to the city council. They are also to implement policies and decisions of the council as the policies and decisions may pertain to each particular board, commission, or committee.

Members shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. Vacancies on any board, commission, or committee shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointments. As long as they remain eligible for the position, board, commission, or committee, members may continue to serve until their successor has been qualified and appointed. Unless otherwise set forth herein, or unless membership is based upon a position, all terms shall commence on January 1st and end on December 31st. Unless otherwise indicated herein, members of boards, commissions, or committees may serve successive terms. Unless otherwise set forth by ordinance, each board, commission, or committee shall meet after the annual appointments have been made and designate a chairperson to conduct the meetings during the coming year. Additional officers, such as a vice chair or secretary may be designated, as needed. A majority of the members of a board, commission, or committee is necessary to constitute a quorum in order to conduct business. Agendas and minutes shall be provided to be posted on the city website.

No member of a board, commission, or committee shall receive any compensation for so serving unless otherwise noted by city ordinance, but may be reimbursed for their authorized and reasonable expenses if such expenses are approved by the city administrator in advance.

HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)
4.12.020 Ad Hoc Committees
These committees are created to deal with a specific issue which is anticipated to have a short duration. Ad Hoc committees generally deal with a single topic and once a solution or recommendation is arrived at, they report to the full city council in a formal city council meeting and the committee is dissolved.
The need for Ad Hoc committees varies from time to time and these committees do not take the place of the city council or planning commission. The number on the committee may vary from project to project as determined by the mayor.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)

4.12.030 Planning Commission
A planning commission is created to address land use issues as set forth in the Highland City Development Code. The planning commission, in those limited instances identified in the Development Code where it is the land use authority, is vested with the authority to make decisions regarding the public's business.
The term of the planning commission members shall commence on February 1st and terminate on January 31st four years later, more specifically outlined in Article 2 of the Highland City Development Code.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)

4.12.040 Development Review Committee
A development review committee is created to address the technical aspects of land use issues relating to the following three items:
Subdivisions,
Awnings signs, and
Development within the Town Center Overlay.
The development review committee consists of the city administrator, public works director, community development director, fire chief, and police chief.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)

4.12.050 Water Advisory Board
The water advisory board is created to advise the mayor and the city council on administrative and policy issues relating to the water provided by the public works department utility division.
Term. The water advisory board shall consist of seven appointed voting members. One member of the board will be the Director of Public Works/Engineer of Highland City, Utah. The mayor shall appoint the other members of the board. The appointments will be for a term of four years, with the term of three board members expiring at the end of even numbered years and the term of the other four board members expiring at the end of odd numbered years. Board members may serve more than one term. The mayor shall designate the terms of the initial board members. Vacancies occurring in the membership of the board shall be filled by appointment by the mayor with advice and consent of the city council.
Purpose. The purpose of the board is to act as a policy advisor to the city council and the mayor on water-related issues. The board will endeavor to promote the capital and fiscal plans previously adopted by the Highland Water Company. The board will advise the city council and mayor on issues such as water rates, capital needs of the water system, capital facilities plans and timetables, water conservation, water acquisitions, etc
Removal from Office. Members appointed by the mayor may be removed at any time by the mayor with the consent of the city council upon a showing of reasonable cause. If any member fails to attend more than one-third of scheduled board meetings within any twelve-month period, at the discretion of the mayor, such member shall be deemed to have resigned from the board.
Eligibility Requirements. A person, to be eligible to be appointed as a member of the board, shall meet the following prerequisites:
Be not less than twenty-one years of age;
Be a resident of the State of Utah;
Shall be actively engaged or employed in an area of expertise in water-related issues that will contribute to the success of the Highland City Public Works Department; and
Must be a user of any of the services supplied by the Highland City Public Works Department.
Meetings. The board shall convene for regular meetings to be held not less than quarterly throughout the year. Special meetings may be ordered by a majority of the board or the chair of the board. Four members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The board may act officially by a majority vote of the quorum.
Election of Chair. Each year the board, at its first regular meeting after January 1st, shall select one of its members as a chair and another of its members as vice chair. The vice chair shall perform the duties of the chair during the absence or disability of the chair. The director of public works shall make available a secretary from his or her staff to serve as staff to the board when required.
Review of Action—Veto Power of Council. All actions taken by the board shall constitute recommendations to the council and mayor (elected officials) and shall not constitute official action by the city. All recommendations shall be reduced to writing and shall be submitted to the council and mayor. The council shall have the power to review, ratify, modify or reject any recommendation submitted to it by the board. The council shall inform the board of action taken by the council on recommendations made by the board.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)

4.12.060 Library Board
A library board is created, pursuant to Utah Code Annotated Sections 9-7-401 through 9-7-410, consisting from five to nine citizens, one of whom shall be a Council Member. The size of the board may fluctuate based on the needs of the library. The size of the board shall be determined by the City Council after receiving a recommendation from the library board.
The term of each board member shall be for three years, which terms are staggered, such that two or three appointments are available each year. Terms begin the first day of July. Board members shall not serve more than two full terms in succession.
Any vacancy occurring for a seat in which the term has not expired on the board shall be for the unexpired term of the departing board member.
The Mayor may remove any board members for misconduct or neglect of duty with the advice and consent of the City Council.
The library board shall maintain and care for the library by making recommendations concerning the use of the library, the amount of fines and fees, and the operation and care of the library. The board may establish policies concerning day to day use and operation of the library and materials to be made available, which do not need specific City Council approval, but are consistent with the policies made by the City Council.
The Library Director shall serve as the executive officer for the library board. 
The library board and City Council shall meet once a year to discuss the operations and care of the library. 
The library board shall create and present bylaws to City Council for approval. The board may also create any board operating procedures as needed that are consistent with the bylaws, municipal code, and state code.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)

HISTORY
Amended by Ord. O-2018-11 on 8/7/2018
Amended by Ord. O-2019-02 on 3/5/2019
4.12.070 Arts Council
An arts council committee is created, consisting of a minimum of three and a maximum of fifteen members, one of whom shall be an elected official. The arts council committee shall foster an appreciation of the arts within the city; make recommendations to the city council concerning cultural events to be sponsored by the city, and encourage privately sponsored cultural events to take place within the city.
The terms of each committee member shall be three years, which terms shall be staggered. No more than two successive terms may be served.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)

4.12.080 Parks, Trails, And Tree Commission
There is hereby created and established a Highland City Parks, Trails and Trees Commission (PTTC). The following provisions shall apply to the commission:

Commission:
The PTTC shall consist of seven (7) members, all of whom must be residents of the City, appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council.
The PTTC may, with the approval of the mayor, create task groups or subcommittees that include persons who are not members of the PTTC and may include non-residents of the city. All such task groups or subcommittees, and all non-commission persons serving on the same, shall first be approved by the mayor.
A member of the city council may be designated as the council liaison to the PTTC.
Term of Office:
All members shall serve a term of three years except the initial appointments to the commission shall be made so that the terms shall be staggered such that no less than two (2) and no more than three (3) terms shall expire in any given year. 
No member may serve more than seven (7) consecutive years.
In the event that a vacancy shall occur, a successor shall be appointed for the remainder of the term of the predecessor.
Terms shall begin on February 1 and end on January 31 of each year.
Chairperson: The initial chair and vice chair shall be appointed by the mayor to serve until January 31 of the following year. Thereafter, at the first meeting of the PTTC on or after February 1 in each year, the members of the commission shall elect a chair and vice chair. In the absence of the chair, the vice chair shall act as chair and shall have all powers of the chair. The term of the chair and vice chair shall be one year, ending January 31.
Compensation: No member or person serving with the commission shall receive any compensation for so serving unless otherwise noted by city ordinance, but may be reimbursed for their authorized and reasonable expenses if such expenses are approved by the city administrator in advance.
Duties and Responsibilities: The PTTC shall be an advisory body to the mayor, city council, planning commission, and city staff regarding the needs and management of the city parks, open space, trails and trees. The PTTC shall have no decision-making or approval authority over the city’s business, actions, property, or personnel. The PTTC is accountable to the mayor and city council and shall carry out following duties and responsibilities under the direction of and as requested by the mayor, city council, planning commission, city administrator, or city staff:
General duties
To adopt bylaws, policies, procedures and regulations for the conduct of its duties and meetings, for consideration of items brought before the commission, and for any other purposes deemed necessary for the functioning of the commission; provided, that such bylaws, policies, procedures and regulations shall be approved by the city council before taking effect.
Meetings of the commission shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the commission may determine. The commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings and its official actions, which shall be immediately filed in the office of the city recorder and shall be a public record.
To follow city and state regulations regarding public bodies. 
To assist in establishing educational and information programs related to parks, trails, trees, and open space.
To develop and manage volunteer programs and volunteers to assist in maintaining and improving parks, trails, and other open spaces.
To provide an annual report to the city council in the first quarter of the calendar year, and additional information as requested.
To facilitate the donation of property and money to the city for the purchase and planting of trees and shrubs on public property and to fund other special events sponsored by the commission with the approval of the mayor. All donations shall be received by the city treasurer or other appropriate city officer according to governing law and city policy and conveyed into a special fund for the purposes set out in this chapter.
Park duties
To review individual city park design plans and provide recommendations to city staff.
To work with staff in the creation and maintenance of a prioritized list of park improvements for all parks in the city.
To review the city’s park master plan and provide suggestions and recommendations to the city as part of the annual report or as otherwise requested.
Trail duties
To work with staff in the creation and maintenance of a prioritized list of trail and trail corridor improvements.
To review the city’s trail master plan and provide suggestions and recommendations to the city as part of the annual report or as otherwise requested.
Tree duties
To assist in the development and administration of a community tree management program for Highland City.
To work with staff in the creation and maintenance of a street tree and landscape tree selection guide.
To work with staff in the creation and maintenance of a street tree inventory database and mapping.
In cooperation with the Highland City Historical Society, to identify and mark notable or historic trees for preservation.
To make recommendations to the city forester regarding the planting, pruning, spraying, removing, and irrigating of public trees and the regulation and control of the grounds surrounding public trees and places insofar as the same may be necessary for the proper growth, care, and protection of the same.
To make recommendations to the city forester regarding the removal of any public or nonpublic tree, or parts thereof, growing on public or private land that may be a nuisance or dangerous to the public.
To communicate with the mayor, city council, and staff regarding continued compliance or nonconforming compliance for the Tree Cities USA designation.
City-owned open space duties
To work with staff in the creation and maintenance of a prioritized list of open space improvements for all open space in the city.
To review the city’s open space master plan and provide suggestions and recommendations to the city as part of the annual report or as otherwise requested.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)

HISTORY
Adopted by Ord. O-2020-04 on 1/14/2020
4.12.100 Compliance With Open And Public Meetings Act
Highland City strives to show transparency in local government and to that end requires each board, committee or commission to comply with notification requirements for meetings and minutes as outlined in Utah Code Annotated Section 52-4.

HMC (Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 2-15-2011)
