Chapter 9.04 CRIMINAL CODE
9.04.010 Criminal Code Adopted
9.04.020 Controlled Substances, Drug Paraphernalia And Imitation Controlled Substances

9.04.010 Criminal Code Adopted
The Utah Criminal Code, as contained in Title 76 of Utah Code Annotated, 1953, as amended through 1997, is adopted as the criminal code of Highland City, and incorporated as part of this code along with such city ordinances as have been adopted relating to certain specific crimes. Where a citation, information, or complaint is issued under the Utah Criminal Code, as adopted by this section it shall be sufficient to use the section number of the Utah Code to designate the section number of the city code which has been violated. Those portions of the Utah Criminal Code, as adopted herein, referring to or dealing with felony, or punishments associated with felonies, and those portions of the above reference Utah Code provisions which are adopted as part of this code dealing with Class "A" misdemeanors, which are not subject to enforcement by the city, along with such other matters as can apply only to the State of Utah and cannot reasonably apply to the City of Highland, are specifically excepted and are not part of this code.

HMC (Ord. 1993-8 § I; Ord. 1997-19 § 1)
9.04.020 Controlled Substances, Drug Paraphernalia And Imitation Controlled Substances
The Utah Controlled Substances Act, as contained in Chapter 37 of Title 58, Utah Code Annotated, 1953, as amended through 1997, is adopted and incorporated as part of this code. Where citation, information or complaint is issued under the above referenced state code, as adopted by this section, it shall be sufficient to use the section number of the Utah Code to designate the section number of the city code which has been violated. Those portions of the above referenced state code, as adopted herein, referring to or dealing with felony, or punishments associated with felonies, and those portions of the above reference Utah Code provisions which are adopted as part of this code dealing with Class "A" misdemeanors which are not subject to enforcement by the city or such other matters as can apply only to the State of Utah and cannot reasonably apply to the city, are specifically excepted and are not part of this code.
The Utah Drug Paraphernalia Act, as contained in Chapter 37, of Title 58, Utah Code Annotated, 1953, as amended through 1997, is adopted and incorporated as part of this code. Where a citation, information, or complaint is issued under the above reference state code, as adopted by this section, it shall be sufficient to use the section number of the Utah Code to designate the section number of the city code which has been violated. Those portions of the above referenced state code, as adopted herein, referring to or dealing with felony, or punishments associated with felonies, and those portions of the above reference Utah Code provisions which are adopted as part of this code dealing with Class "A" misdemeanors which are not subject to enforcement by the city or such other matters as can apply only to the State of Utah and cannot reasonably apply to the city, are specifically excepted and are not part of this code.
The Utah Imitation Controlled Substances Act, as contained in Chapter 37b of Title 58, Utah Code Annotated, 1953, as amended through 1997, is adopted and incorporated as of this code. Where a citation, information or complaint is issued under the above referenced state code, as adopted by this section, it shall be sufficient to use the section number of the Utah Code to designate the section number of the city code which has been violated. Those portions of the above referenced state code, as adopted herein, referring to or dealing with felony, or punishments associated with felonies, and those portions of the above referenced Utah Code provisions which are adopted as part of this code dealing with Class "A" misdemeanors which are not subject to enforcement by the city or such other matters as can apply only to the State of Utah and cannot reasonably apply to the city, are specifically excepted and are not part of this code.
HMC (Ord. 1993-8 § IV; Ord. 1997-19 § 4)

Chapter 9.08 LOITERING
9.08.010 Title
9.08.020 Purpose
9.08.030 Loitering Defined
9.08.040 Acts Prohibited
9.08.050 Violation; Penalty

9.08.010 Title
This chapter shall be known as the loitering ordinance of the City of Highland.

HMC (Ord. 1993-3 § 1-1)
9.08.020 Purpose
The purpose of this chapter is to abate the practice of loitering within the city and to impose fines or other punishment upon persons engaging in such conduct.

HMC (Ord. 1993-3 § 1-2)
9.08.030 Loitering Defined
"Loitering" is defined as standing around or moving slowly about, spending time idly; sauntering; delaying; lingering or lagging behind or sitting or lying around or upon.

HMC (Ord. 1993-3 § 1-3)
9.08.040 Acts Prohibited
A person is guilty of loitering if such person:
Appears at a place or at a time under circumstances that cause or warrant alarm for the safety of persons or property in the area or vicinity, and upon inquiry by a law enforcement officer fails to give a reasonably credible account of his or her identity, conduct or purpose at such time and place; or
Loiters in or about a school, by walking, sitting, standing, or by being in or upon a vehicle or conveyance, not having any relationship involving custody or responsibility for a student or any other specific legitimate reason for being there, and not having written permission from anyone authorized to grant the same, and upon inquiry of a law enforcement officer such person fails to give a reasonable credible account of his or her identity, conduct, or purposes; or
Loiters in or about a building, house, lot, street, sidewalk or other public or private place, either by walking, sitting, standing, or by sitting in or upon a vehicle or conveyance, without apparent reason and under circumstances which justify suspicion that he or she may be engaged in or about to engage in a crime, and upon inquiry of a law enforcement official, such person fails to give a reasonably credible account of his or her identity, conduct, or purposes; or
Is on or in any public area, as hereafter defined, and which person:
Remains, wanders idly or prowls:
In a manner or at a time not usual for law-abiding people, or
Under circumstances that warrant reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the area or vicinity; and
Refuses to obey the command of a police officer to move on, or provide to such police officer a lawful reason for remaining on or in said public area;
The police officer's command shall be lawfully given when alleged loitering by such person creates or causes to be created:
A breach of the peace, or
The actual or attempted obstruction, molestation or interference of any person lawfully in any public area, as hereinafter defined, in such a manner as to cause such other person reasonably to fear for his or her safety, or
The obstruction or attempted obstruction of the free, normal flow of vehicles or pedestrians in such public area, or
The disturbance of any person acting lawfully on or in any public place;
For the purposes of subsection (A)(4) of this section, "public area" means any place open to the public, including, but not limited to, any common public area of any shopping mall, public way, street, highway, alley or park.
No person shall be convicted under this section if the explanation such person gives of his or her conduct and purposes was true and, if believed by the law enforcement officer at the time, would have dispelled the alarm.
HMC (Ord. 1993-3 § 1-5)

9.08.050 Violation; Penalty
Loitering is a Class C misdemeanor.

HMC (Ord. 1993-3 § 1-4)
Chapter 9.12 CURFEW
9.12.010 Purpose
9.12.020 Definitions
9.12.030 Sixteen-Year-Old Curfew
9.12.040 Eighteen-Year-Old Curfew
9.12.050 Parental Liability
9.12.060 Exceptions
9.12.070 Enforcement

9.12.010 Purpose
The governing body of Highland City finds, due to a seemingly ever-increasing incidence of violence and other crime among juveniles in Utah County, being both drug-related and gang-related, that such crimes may be significantly inhibited and reduced by the enactment and enforcement of local laws establishing a curfew prohibiting juveniles from remaining idly and purposelessly on the public streets late at night.

HMC (Ord. 1994-4 § 1)
9.12.020 Definitions
As used in this chapter the following terms are defined in this section:

"Care and custody" means the legal authority of a parent or guardian to supervise or otherwise be responsible for a minor, or the express authority given from such parent or legal guardian of a minor to a responsible adult to supervise or otherwise be responsible for the activities and care of the minor.

"Emergency errand" means any errand or travel undertaken to directly and immediately seek to prevent or reduce the consequences of an illness or injury, criminal or potentially criminal activity, or fire or other accident and shall include the seeking of aid and assistance from medical or emergency response personnel or the purchase of medications.

"Minor" means any unmarried, unemancipated person who is not a member of the armed forces of the United States and who is under the age of sixteen years for the purposes of Section 9.12.030 or who is under the age of eighteen years for the purpose of Section 9.12.040.

"Public places" means any place open to the public, whether publicly or privately owned, including but not limited to parking lots and the interiors and exteriors of schools, churches, and commercial establishments such as restaurants, stores or places of entertainment.

HMC (Ord. 1994-4 § 2)
9.12.030 Sixteen-Year-Old Curfew
It is unlawful for any minor under the age of sixteen years to remain or loiter upon any of the sidewalks, streets, alleys or public places in Utah County, between the hours of eleven p.m. and five a.m. the following morning.

HMC (Ord. 1994-4 § 3)
9.12.040 Eighteen-Year-Old Curfew
It is unlawful for any minor under the age of eighteen years to remain or loiter upon any of the sidewalks, streets, alleys or public places in Utah County, between the hours of eleven p.m. and five a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the following morning hours of one a.m. and five a.m. Saturday through Sunday.

HMC (Ord. 1994-4 § 4)
9.12.050 Parental Liability
It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person having care and custody of any minor to knowingly allow or permit the minor to violate the provisions of this chapter.

HMC (Ord. 1994-4 § 5)
9.12.060 Exceptions
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any circumstance in which the minor is:

Accompanied by a parent, guardian, or other responsible adult having care and custody of such minor;
Engaged in a legitimate trade, employment, occupation or errand which requires the minor's presence in or on the sidewalks, streets, alleys or public places while working at or traveling to or from such employment;
Engaged on an emergency errand directed by the minor's parent, guardian or other responsible person having care and custody;
In a motor vehicle engaged in normal interstate travel beginning in, travelling through, or ending in Utah County;
Attending or engaged in travelling between the minor's home or place of residence and a place where any religious, municipal, social, entertainment, sporting, political, library, or school function is occurring; or
Within the boundaries of the minor's place of residence.
HMC (Ord. 1994-4 § 6)

9.12.070 Enforcement
Any minor who is in violation of the provisions of this chapter is subject to arrest and citation.
Upon arrest, the minor shall be returned to the custody of the parent, guardian or other person charged with the care and custody of the minor.
It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person charged with the care and custody of a minor who is in violation of this chapter to knowingly refuse to appear and take custody of said minor within a reasonable time after being ordered to do so by a peace officer.
HMC (Ord. 1994-4 § 7)

Chapter 9.13 TRESPASSING
9.13.010 Trespassing

9.13.010 Trespassing
It shall be Highland City's policy to adopt, implement and enforce Section 76-6-206, Criminal Trespass, of the Utah State Code, and any other applicable state and/or federal regulations.
New editions of the Utah State Criminal Trespass Code shall be automatically adopted unless otherwise specified or amended herein.
All persons found in violation of this provision shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor. The minimum fine for a first offense shall be two hundred fifty dollars. The minimum fine for a second offense shall be five hundred dollars. The fine for all subsequent offenses of this provision after the second offense shall be a minimum of one thousand dollars. Fines, as established herein, are minimum fines. Violations of this section can be subject to increased fines when deemed appropriate by the court, but not to exceed one thousand dollars. Each offense shall be deemed a separate violation of this provision.
Vandalism of signs, fences, and/or public or private property attempting to denote and give notice against entering shall constitute a separate violation of this provision and subject to a separate fine as noted in Section 9.13.010.
This section does not prohibit the use of public or private property by the following:
Emergency vehicles;
Vehicles of commerce in the course of normal business operations;
Vehicles being operated on property devoted to commercial or industrial purposes where such operation is in conjunction with commercial or industrial use and permission for such operation is implied or expressly given by the person in possession of said property;
Vehicles operated on property actually used for residential purposes, where such vehicles are there at the express or implied invitation of the owner or occupant;
Vehicles being operated on public or private parking lots, where permission to do so is implied, or expressly given, by the person in possession of such lot.
HMC (Ord. 2003-5)

Chapter 9.16 ALARM SYSTEMS
9.16.010 Definitions
9.16.020 Legislative Intent
9.16.030 Regulation
9.16.040 Unlawful To Operate Without License
9.16.050 License; Application; Content; General
9.16.060 License; Application; Contents; Additional
9.16.070 License; Applicant; Personal Information Required
9.16.080 Application Fee Required
9.16.090 Investigation Fees; Required Fees Charged
9.16.100 Investigation Fee Not Refunded
9.16.110 Withdrawal Of Application; Refund
9.16.120 License; Corporation; Partnerships; Associations; Changes In Membership
9.16.130 License; Issuance; Fee; Renewal
9.16.140 Bond Required, New Business; Alternative Of Certificate Of Deposit, Requirements Based On Actual False Alarms Of Business; Exemptions
9.16.150 Licensee Responsible For The Acts Of Employees
9.16.160 Provisions For Compliance; Time
9.16.170 License; Suspension; Revocation; Limitation
9.16.180 Alarm Systems Businesses Located Out Of Local Area; Requirement Of A Resident Agent
9.16.190 Business; Employers And Employees; Registration Card Required; Additional Grounds For Denial
9.16.200 Application For Electrical Permit Required; Permit Not Assignable Or Transferable
9.16.210 Inspection
9.16.220 Sirens Not To Be Audible Outside Premises
9.16.230 Instructions As To The Operation Of The System; User Responsibility For Maintenance
9.16.240 Response Alarms Condition; False Alarms; Exceptions
9.16.250 Audible Alarm System Cutoff; Automatic Dialing Systems
9.16.260 Operational Defects To Be Remedied
9.16.270 Fee For False Alarms; Accounting; Method Of Billing And Collection
9.16.280 Notices
9.16.290 Excessive False Alarms
9.16.300 Violation; Penalty; Alarm System User
9.16.310 Violation; Penalty; Alarm Systems Businesses; Licensed Security And/or Private Patrol Businesses

9.16.010 Definitions
As used in this chapter, the following terms are defined in this section:

"Activated alarm system" means an alarm system which has been set, or turned on; in which condition it will emit a noise, turn on lights, dial a telephone or send a signal to a monitoring station, or any other means of signaling, when the alarm has been activated.

"Alarm condition" means that a situation exists, determined by an alarm monitoring business, or other means, which is used to summon emergency response personnel,

"Alarm system" means any mechanism, equipment or device which is designed to detect an unauthorized entry into any building or onto any property, or to direct attention to a crime in progress, or to signal an emergency of any kind and to signal the above occurrence either by a local or audible alarm or by a silent or remote alarm. Alarm systems shall not include alarms installed in motor vehicles.

"Alarm systems business" means any person engaging in the business of planning, installing, servicing maintaining, repairing or replacing, or monitoring alarm systems in the city. "Alarm systems business" shall also mean any person acting as a contractor or subcontractor for or with an alarm systems business as described.

"Applicant" means any person who has requested, or is about to request, licensing as an alarm systems business, or any person who has requested or is about to request a building permit to install an alarm system at a particular location in the city.

"Building official" means the official of the building inspection department of the city, or his designee.

"Council" or "city council" means the City Council of Highland City, Utah.

"Emergency response personnel" means, but is not limited to the police and fire departments and ambulance services.

"Employee" means a person who is employed by an alarm systems business and who plans, sells, installs, services, maintains, repairs, monitors or replaces alarm systems in the city.

"False alarm" means an actual alarm signal transmitted in the absence of an alarm condition which results in emergency response personnel being dispatched to the location of the alarm.

"Local or audible alarm" means an alarm, which, when activated, emits a loud noise at or near the protected area without notifying an alarm monitoring station.

"Responder" means a private patrol business, licensed in accordance with the provisions of Utah Law and the city, or the owner of the home, business, structure or facility experiencing an alarm condition.

"Manually activated alarm" means an alarm system which is activated manually, and which transmits a signal to an alarm monitoring station indicating an emergency exists or a crime in progress.

"User" means a person, who owns, or is in control of the premises protected or intended to be protected by an alarm system.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 1)
9.16.020 Legislative Intent
As the city's population has grown, more residential and commercial property owners are turning to privately monitored security alarm systems to provide additional protection for their properties. Commensurate with the growth in the number of private alarm systems installed within the city, experience in other communities has shown a corresponding increase in the number of false alarm reports received by the police department. In response to the proliferation of alarm systems and the city council's concern for the public's best interest from a safety standpoint as it relates to the increased incidents of false alarms, it is necessary that rules and regulations be adopted to control the licensing and operation of alarm systems businesses and the establishment of a process whereby the city can recoup the expenses incurred in responding to false alarms.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 2)
9.16.030 Regulation
All persons, except an alarm user as defined in this chapter, shall be licensed and subject to regulation, and the license may be suspended, limited, or revoked for violation of the provisions of this chapter, the laws of the State of Utah, other chapters of the city, or for any other cause deemed sufficient by the council in the exercise of its sole discretion. In conformity with the policy of this chapter, the following persons are declared not to be qualified to hold a license under the provisions of this chapter:

A person who has been convicted of a crime involving theft, fraud, dishonesty, receiving or possessing stolen property, any narcotics violation whatsoever or any sex offense;
A person whose license, whether issued under the provisions of this chapter, or those chapters or statutes of any other agency lawfully engaged in the licensing or regulation of alarm systems businesses, has been revoked for cause;
A person who, at the time of renewal of any license issued under this chapter would not be eligible for such license upon a first application;
A partnership, limited partnership or association, unless all of the members of such partnership, limited partnership or association are qualified to obtain a license;
A corporation, unless it is incorporated in the State of Utah, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under Utah law to transact business in Utah;
A corporation, if an officer or city recorder thereof would not be eligible to receive a license for any reason which would disqualify an individual applicant.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 3)

9.16.040 Unlawful To Operate Without License
It is unlawful for any person to conduct any alarm systems business as described in this chapter without first having obtained a license therefor.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 4)
9.16.050 License; Application; Content; General
Whenever a person desires to conduct any alarm systems business in the city, such person shall make application in writing to the city recorder to obtain a license therefor; and such application shall contain the following:

The name and residence address of the applicant; and
The classification of the license sought, the business address for which the license is sought, where the operation will be conducted; and
The names and residential addresses of all persons owning an interest in and managing the business, together with a statement as to the percentage of the business owned by each individual. Each license applicant shall designate on the application form the name of an agent residing within the county who is responsible for the conduct of the business and authorized to immediately answer to the council or its agents should inquiry or action be deemed necessary; and
A consent for police department and city recorder investigation of the applicant's background, including, but not limited to, financial background, employment history, and criminal record. In all cases where the applicant for an alarm systems license is a corporation, the names and residential addresses of the officers or directors of the corporation shall be listed on the application. In all such cases, the city recorder or the chief of police shall determine who of the principal officers and directors of such corporation shall require background investigations;
All applicants for an alarm systems license shall state for each person interested in the business, his name, and place of residence, whether or not he is a legal resident of the United States, whether or not he has been convicted of a crime which would be considered a felony under the laws of the State of Utah, or any misdemeanor crime, other than minor traffic offenses, and any other information the city recorder may require.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 5)

9.16.060 License; Application; Contents; Additional
All applications shall contain such information as the council or its authorized officers by rule or regulation not inconsistent with law prescribe. Each licensee shall designate on the application form the agent residing within the county who is responsible for the conduct of the business and authorized to immediately answer to the council or its agents should inquiry or action be deemed necessary.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 6)
9.16.070 License; Applicant; Personal Information Required
All applicants for an alarm systems license shall state for each person interested in the business, his name and place of residence, whether or not he is a legal resident of the United States, whether or not he has been convicted of a crime which would be considered a felony under the laws of the State of Utah, or any misdemeanor crime, other than minor traffic offenses, and any other information the city Recorder may require, all to be set forth in the application.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 7)
9.16.080 Application Fee Required
No investigation shall be made of any applicant for an alarm systems license prior to the payment by the applicant, and receipt of such fee, by the city recorder, and no license shall be issued until all appropriate fees are paid.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 8)
9.16.090 Investigation Fees; Required Fees Charged
Any person applying for an alarm systems license is required to deposit with the city recorder an investigation fee as determined by the Highland City consolidated fee schedule for each person required to be licensed.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 9)
9.16.100 Investigation Fee Not Refunded
Even though an applicant is denied a license after investigation, no part of the investigation fees deposited shall be returned to the applicant.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 10)
9.16.110 Withdrawal Of Application; Refund
If any applicant withdraws his application prior to the beginning of an investigation, all fees deposited shall be returned to the applicant.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 11)
9.16.120 License; Corporation; Partnerships; Associations; Changes In Membership
In the case of a corporate licensee, any and all changes in the officers or directors of such corporation shall be reported to the city recorder within thirty days of the appointment or election of such officers and directors. Such officers or directors shall be required to qualify for a license as required by this chapter.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 12)
9.16.130 License; Issuance; Fee; Renewal
Upon receipt of the results of the background investigation from the police department, the city recorder will approve or deny the application. If the application is denied the applicant may appeal such denial to the council.
The license fee for an alarm systems business shall be a specified in the city schedule of fees, payable in advance, and shall be renewed annually.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 13)

9.16.140 Bond Required, New Business; Alternative Of Certificate Of Deposit, Requirements Based On Actual False Alarms Of Business; Exemptions
The bond required by this chapter is conditioned upon the licensee to fully comply with the requirements of payment of all license fees, and fees for false alarms, due the city.
No new license shall be issued to conduct any alarm systems business until the applicant files a surety bond with the city recorder in the amount of ten thousand dollars, with surety from a company licensed to do business in the State of Utah. The bond shall be taken in the name of the city, and legal action on the bond may be brought by the city to recover delinquent license fees and/or fees for false alarms.
Every new alarm systems business shall maintain such surety bond in full force and effect during the first year of licensure under this chapter, and upon failure to do so, its license shall be suspended until such bond is renewed; and
After one year of licensure, in lieu of the bond described in subsection B of this section, the licensee may deposit with the city recorder, a certificate of deposit in the amount of three thousand five hundred dollars. The certificate of deposit shall be made payable to the licensee and the city jointly, shall be nonnegotiable by the licensee without the signature of the city, but shall be negotiable by the city individually.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 14)

9.16.150 Licensee Responsible For The Acts Of Employees
Every licensee shall be responsible for the acts of his/her employees committed during the course and scope of employment. In any license suspension, limitation or revocation proceedings, the fact that the licensee did not have actual knowledge of the events complained of shall be no defense, and every licensee hereunder accepts his license subject to said condition.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 15)
9.16.160 Provisions For Compliance; Time
Those licensees, responders and users not in conformity with the provisions of this chapter at the date of adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall have a period of ninety days from the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter to conform to the requirements thereof.
Any alarm systems business which is unable to comply with any debt due the city for false alarms as imposed by this chapter within the ninety-day period, may apply for an additional ninety-day extension. Such request shall be made in writing to the city recorder prior to the end of the first seventy-five-day period, shall be signed by the licensee, and shall include a detailed explanation of the reasons for requesting an extension.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 16)

9.16.170 License; Suspension; Revocation; Limitation
The council may deem that any activity on the part of the licensee or employees, or a person previously found suitable, which is contrary to the public health, safety, morals, good order, or general welfare of the residents of the city or which violates any ordinance or regulation of the city or the State of Utah is grounds for disciplinary action which may result in a suspension, limitation or revocation of the alarm systems license. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, each of the following reasons are declared to be a basis for disciplinary action:

Conviction of the licensee of any crime involving theft, fraud, dishonesty, receiving or possessing stolen property, any narcotics violation or any sex offense; or
Conducting an alarm systems business in an unlawful manner or in a manner detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare; or
Each licensee who violates any provision of this title; or
Each licensee who knowingly fails to report or conceals from the council a full disclosure of the names of all persons having an interest in the ownership of, or receiving any remuneration whatsoever under a license in which he has an interest; or
Each licensee who knowingly fails to report or conceals from proper authority any information which it is his duty to supply under any statute, ordinance or regulation of the state or the city; or
Each licensee who, for conduct subsequent to the issuance of a license, becomes ineligible to hold an alarm systems license as set out in the statutes, ordinances and regulations of the state or city; or
Each licensee who made a misrepresentation of a material fact in his application to obtain a license; or
Each licensee whose alarm systems license in any place in the State of Utah has been revoked; or
Each licensee who employs a person without a registration card as required by this chapter.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 17)

9.16.180 Alarm Systems Businesses Located Out Of Local Area; Requirement Of A Resident Agent
Any alarm systems business not physically located in Utah County shall conform to the following provisions:

The resident agent shall be a full-time employee, not a subcontractor, of the alarm systems business; and
The resident shall reside within a fifty-mile radius of the city. For purposes of this subsection, the point from which the fifty-mile radius shall be measured is from the city hall of the city; and
The resident agent shall possess two years of demonstrable experience in the alarm systems business; and
The resident agent shall physically sign the monthly false alarm billing statement received from the city.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 18)

9.16.190 Business; Employers And Employees; Registration Card Required; Additional Grounds For Denial
All employees, who through the course of their duties as an employee of an alarm systems business licensed under this chapter, and whose job function is that of installation, maintenance or repair of an alarm system, must secure a registration card from the chief of police. The registration card must be carried upon the person at all times while performing duties in the city, and is nontransferable.
In addition to the requirements imposed by state law, no registration shall be issued by the chief of police to any individual who has been convicted of any crime of moral turpitude.
When an employee is terminated, or resigns, from employment with an alarm systems business, it is unlawful for the employee to fail to immediately surrender his registration card to his employer; and, it is unlawful for the employer to fail to immediately deliver in person, or mail by registered or certified mail, such surrendered registration card to the chief of police.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 19)

9.16.200 Application For Electrical Permit Required; Permit Not Assignable Or Transferable
No person shall install, operate, maintain or engage another person to install, operate or maintain an alarm system at a particular location unless a building permit (electric) as required by city ordinance, or the Uniform Building Code, has been applied for and issued.
A permit issued under this section shall not be assignable or transferable.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 20)

9.16.210 Inspection
The building official is authorized to make inspections of alarm systems that have been installed within the city for the purpose of determining whether such systems are being maintained in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. The building official shall request the owner or lessee of the premises on which the alarm system is installed, or any other person who may lawfully give his consent, to admit the building official onto the premises for the purpose of making an inspection of the alarm system.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 21)
9.16.220 Sirens Not To Be Audible Outside Premises
It is unlawful to install or maintain any alarm system which, upon activation, emits an audible sound, that could reasonably be confused with the siren emitted by an emergency vehicle. The audible warning system of an emergency vehicle is not a siren by this definition.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 22)
9.16.230 Instructions As To The Operation Of The System; User Responsibility For Maintenance
It shall be the responsibility of all alarm systems users to see that all employees and persons regularly using the premises on which the alarm is installed be instructed in the proper operating procedures to avoid false alarm signals.
Any button installed in an alarm system, intended to be depressed manually for the purpose of summoning emergency personnel, shall be referred to as "manually activated alarm" and instructions shall be given that it is not to be used unless there is an actual emergency.
It shall be the responsibility of the alarm system user to cause the system to be maintained in reliable operating condition.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 23)

9.16.240 Response Alarms Condition; False Alarms; Exceptions
When the alarms systems business, or responder, notifies emergency personnel of an actual alarm condition, it shall provide the following information:
The name of the party reporting the alarm condition; and
The time, address and phone number of the alarm condition, and the type of alarm; and
The precise location of the alarm (if there is more than one floor), the type of alarm; and
The name and description of the responder (uniformed, armed or not armed) at the location and a description of the vehicle driven by the responder, if known; and
The type of instrumentation, or verification, used to determine that an alarm condition exists, if any.
In the event that a false alarm condition exists, it shall be the responsibility of the alarm system user to comply with the requirements regarding the notification of responsible persons who will render all necessary service and assistance to restore the alarm to normal condition or to reset the alarm.
For purposes of this subsection, the alarm systems business, and/or user, may contract with a licensed security or private patrol business to perform the function of the responder. Such responder business shall be required to conform to the provisions of this chapter as if an actual licensee when engaged in the alarm responder business.
Alarm systems businesses that request police response to an alarm condition shall maintain a record of all emergency personnel calls stating the time, date and location of the alarm, and if the alarm is not caused by an actual crime in progress, shall state the corrective action taken to prevent the reoccurrence of the false alarm. This record shall be maintained for a period of six months, and shall be made available for inspection by the police department or city recorder at any time during normal business hours.
All alarm systems maintained by any licensed alarm systems business shall terminate in an office of a licensed alarm system business. The alarm systems business, having reason to believe there is an alarm condition, will immediately notify the police department dispatch by telephone.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 24)

9.16.250 Audible Alarm System Cutoff; Automatic Dialing Systems
Every alarm system which uses an audible alarm device to attract the attention of the public shall be equipped with an automatic twenty minute cutoff device, or shall be silenced manually by the user or his representative within twenty minutes after activation.
This section shall also apply to all alarm systems currently installed or being installed.
This section does not preempt Section 9.16.230 which makes it unlawful for siren type alarms to be audible outside the premises wherein the alarm is installed.
Alarm devices which automatically dial telephone numbers must be monitored at an interim monitoring station.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 25)

9.16.260 Operational Defects To Be Remedied
The sensory mechanisms used in connection with alarm systems shall be adjusted to suppress false alarms so that the device will not be activated by impulses due to transient pressure changes in water pipes, short flashes of light, wind noises such as rattling or vibrating of doors and windows, vehicular noises adjacent to the installation or other forces unrelated to genuine alarms. This section shall also apply to all alarm systems currently installed or being installed.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 26)
9.16.270 Fee For False Alarms; Accounting; Method Of Billing And Collection
All false alarms shall be billed monthly to the alarm systems business, or in the absence of an alarm systems business, the user, at a rate determined by the city council.
The emergency services personnel shall maintain a monthly, computer-generated record of all alarms occurring in the city. Such record shall be available for review by an alarm systems business, or a user, by appointment, through the appropriate emergency services office; and
False alarms, which are attributed to an alarm systems business, shall be invoiced to said business monthly, and payment shall be made to the city within thirty days of the invoice date; and
False alarms, which are attributed to a user, shall be invoiced by notice of the total monthly charges due on the user's monthly city utility bill. If the user does not have a city utility bill, it shall be billed separately and collectable in any manner authorized by law.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 27)

9.16.280 Notices
Notice or billing from the city to any alarm system business or alarm user shall be deemed to have been given or rendered on the date such notice or billing is deposited in the United States mail, first class postage, prepaid, addressed to the alarm system business at its place of operation on file with the city recorder or to the alarm user's residence address. A certificate of mailing signed by the person who mailed the notice shall be prima facia evidence of the fact that the notice was mailed.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 28)
9.16.290 Excessive False Alarms
If an excessive number of false alarms occur at any alarm location, written notice shall be given by the police department to the alarm systems user responsible for the system to take corrective action within fourteen calendar days to prevent future false alarms. An excessive number of false alarms shall be deemed to be:
More than three false alarms in any thirty-day period; or
More than four false alarms in any ninety-day period; or
More than five false alarms in any one hundred eighty-day period; or
More than six false alarms in any three hundred sixty-day period.
If the corrective action is not accomplished and communicated in writing to the police department within fourteen days by the alarm systems user, a duly authorized representative of the city may issue a misdemeanor citation to the alarm system user. Corrective action shall require written certification by the alarm systems user that an inspection has been conducted and that the alarm system is safe and reliable.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 29)

9.16.300 Violation; Penalty; Alarm System User
Any alarm system user violating any of the terms and provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a Class "C" misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished, not to exceed the maximum allowable fine under Utah law, or by imprisonment, or by both fine and imprisonment.
The minimum fine permissible under subsection A of this section shall be two hundred fifty dollars plus court costs.
HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 30)

9.16.310 Violation; Penalty; Alarm Systems Businesses; Licensed Security And/or Private Patrol Businesses
Any person violating any of the terms and provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of Class "C" misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by fine or by imprisonment or by both fine and imprisonment; and shall subject the licensee to suspension, limitation or revocation of his license. Any person being adjudged guilty of a violation of this chapter, or any of the provisions or prohibitions thereof may, in the discretion of the council, be denied a license thereafter.

HMC (Ord. 98-16 § 31)

10.04.010 Adoption Of Utah Code Annotated Provisions
Chapter 12 of Title 27 of Utah Code Annotated, 1953, as amended through 1997 title "Highway Code" is adopted and incorporated as part of the Municipal Code of Highland City. Where a citation, information or complaint is issued under Chapter 12 of Title 27 of Utah Code Annotated, 1953, as amended through 1997, as adopted herein, it shall be sufficient to use the section number of the Utah Code to designate the section number of the city code. Those portions of the Highway Code, as adopted herein, referring to or dealing with a felony, or punishments associated with felonies, and those portions of the above reference Utah Code provisions which are adopted as part of the municipal code of the city dealing with Class "A" misdemeanors which are not subject to enforcement by the city along with such other matters as can apply only to the State of Utah and cannot reasonably apply to the city, are specifically excepted and are not part of the adopted or the revised chapter of the city.
Sections 301 through 310 of Chapter 22 of Title 31A of Utah Code Annotated, 1953, as amended through 1997, entitled "Motor Vehicle Insurance" are adopted and incorporated as part of this code. Where a citation, information or complaint is issued under the above referenced State Code, as adopted by this section, it shall be sufficient to use the section number of the Utah Code to designate this section number of the city code which has been violated. Those portions of the above referenced State Code, as adopted herein, referring to or dealing with felony, or punishments associated with felonies, and those portions of the above reference Utah Code provisions which are adopted as part of this code dealing with Class "A" misdemeanors which are not subject to enforcement by the city or such other matters as can apply only to the State of Utah and cannot reasonably apply to the city, are specifically excepted and are not part of the above or this code.
Chapters 1, 2, 6, 7, 8 12a, 22 and 25 of Title 41 of Utah Code Annotated, 1953, as amended through 1997, dealing with motor vehicles, are adopted and incorporated as part of this code. Where a citation, information or complaint is issued under the above referenced State Code, as adopted by this section, it shall be sufficient to use the section number of the Utah Code to designate the section number of the city code which has been violated. Those portions of the above referenced State Code, as adopted herein, referring to or dealing with felony, or punishments associated with felonies, and those portions of the above referenced Utah Code provisions which are adopted as part of this code dealing with Class "A" misdemeanors which are not subject to enforcement by the city or such other matters as can apply only to the State of Utah and cannot reasonably apply to the city, are specifically excepted and are not part of the above or this code.
HMC (Ord. 1993-8 § II; Ord. 1997-19 § 2)

10.08.010 Operation Of Motor-Driven Cycles In City Parks; Violation; Penalty
No person shall operate motor or motor-driven cycles or snowmobiles in Highland City parks. Furthermore, no person shall operate and no owner of a recreation vehicle shall give another permission to operate in a recreational vehicle in Highland City parks, except when operated on a roadway designated by the City as open to such vehciles.
A first violation of this section is punishable by an infraction. A subsequent violation of this section is punishable by a Class "C" misdemeanor.
HMC (Ord. 1983-5)

HISTORY
Amended by Ord. O-2018-04 on 2/20/2018
10.08.020 Sale Of Vehicles On Private Property; Violation; Penalty
It shall be unlawful for the owner of a motor vehicle or trailer to park it or allow it to be parked on a vacant lot or property owned by another person for the purpose of displaying it for sale, unless the owner or lessee of the property on which it is parked has a city business license to engage in the business of selling motor vehicles or trailers at that location. It shall also be unlawful for the owner or lessee of such property to allow another person to park a motor vehicle or trailer on the property for the purpose of displaying it for sale unless such owner or lessee of the property has a city business license to engage in the business of selling motor vehicles or trailers at that location.
The provisions of this section shall not be interpreted as prohibiting a person from selling or displaying for sale his own personal vehicle or trailer on his own property providing that:
The property in question is his primary place of residence;
The vehicle or trailer in question was not obtained primarily for the purpose of resale; and
A total of no more than two such vehicles or trailers are displayed at any one time.
A first violation of this section is punishable by an infraction. A subsequent violation of this section is punishable by a Class "C" misdemeanor. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense.  
Any vehicle or trailer which remains parked in violation of this section after reasonable attempt to contact and inform the owner thereof may be impounded at the owner's expense. Reasonable attempt to contact shall include:
Placing written notice of violation on the vehicle or trailer and expiration of twenty-four hours after such notice is placed; or
Giving verbal notice in person or by telephone to the owner of the vehicle or trailer and expiration of one hour after such notice is given.
HISTORY
Amended by Ord. O-2018-04 on 2/20/2018
10.08.030 Sale Of Vehicles, Trailers On Streets And Highways
It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of a motor vehicle or trailer to park it or allow it to be parked on any highway, street, or shoulder area for the purpose of displaying it for sale. As used in this section, “displaying it for sale” shall be defined as:
Parking and leaving a motor vehicle or trailer in one location, with a “For Sale” sign or similar device, displayed on or in the vehicle.
Parking and leaving a motor vehicle or trailer in a publicly owned area, with a “For Sale” sign or similar device, displayed on or in the vehicle.
A first violation of this section is punishable by an infraction. A subsequent violation of this section is punishable by a Class "C" misdemeanor. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense.
Any vehicle or trailer which remains parked in violation of this section after reasonable attempt to contact and inform the owner thereof may be impounded at the owner's expense. Reasonable attempt to contact shall include:
Placing written notice of violation on the vehicle or trailer and expiration of twenty-four hours after such notice is placed; or
Giving verbal notice in person or by telephone to the owner of the vehicle or trailer and expiration of one hour after such notice is given.
HISTORY
Adopted by Ord. O-2020-25 on 8/18/2020
10.08.040 Parking Oversized Vehicles Upon City Streets
It is unlawful for any person to leave, park or station upon any street in Highland City any unattended vehicle or trailer which:
Is licensed for more than twelve thousand pounds gross; or
Is a combination of motor vehicles in such a position which creates a traffic hazard or impedes traffic flow; or
Is commonly referred to as a "semi-tractor"; or
Is a camper, travel trailer or boat, or any other trailer parked for longer than forty-eight hours; or
Is what is commonly referred to as construction equipment including back hoes, transport trailers, excavation equipment, etc.
Exceptions. The temporary parking of moving vans, delivery trucks and service vehicles for a reasonable time to accommodate loading or unloading or the performance of service.
A first violation of this section is punishable by an infraction. A subsequent violation of this section is punishable by a Class "C" misdemeanor. Any vehicle parked in violation of this section may be removed by the city at owner's expense. 
HMC (Ord. 1984-4 §§ 1, 2; Ord. 1997-23 § 1)

10.08.050 Parking Of Motor Vehicles On City Streets During Snow Removal
It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicles upon city streets from December 1st to March 31st between the hours of twelve a.m. to eight a.m. and any time snow is present so as to provide access to snow plows for snow removal. For purposes of this chapter "vehicle" shall be interpreted to be any vehicle which obstructs the movement of snow removal equipment or the piling of snow on the park strips, sidewalks, roadway or right-of-way.
A first violation of this section is punishable by an infraction. A subsequent violation of of this section is punishable by a Class "C" misdemeanor. Any vehicle parked in violation of this section may be removed by the city at owner's expense.

10.08.070 Motorized Vehicles Upon City Trials Prohibited
Use of Trails by Motorized Vehicles Prohibited. The use of motorized vehicles of any sort, except those vehicles used by Highland City for the purpose of maintenance and public safety, on any Highland City trail is prohibited unless the trail is clearly marked as approved for such use.
A first violation of this section is punishable by an infraction. A subsequent violation of this section is punishable by a Class "C" misdemeanor.

10.08.080 Designation Of Streets And Highways As Open For Street-Legal All-Terrain Vehicle (ATV) Use
All public streets and highways within the jurisdictional limits of Highland City are designated as open for street-legal type I and type II all-terrain vehicles (ATVs) as defined in Utah Code.

Type I all-terrain vehicles (ATVs) are motor propelled off-highway vehicles designed with a seat to be straddled by the operator and type II ATVs are all-terrain vehicles which are motor propelled off-highway vehicles designed to have side by side seating (also known as "mini trucks", "Kei" trucks or "side by sides"). To be legally driven on the streets of Highland each type II ATV shall meet all state requirements as defined by Title 41, Utah Code.
Unauthorized ATVs are not permitted on any trail, sidewalk or in or upon any public open space.
Authorized vehicles include city appropriated ATVs or other vehicles specifically used for the purpose of law enforcement, public safety or maintenance of those trails and lands (see Section 10.08.060).
If an OHV/ATV is used only on a farm or ranch or for other agricultural or irrigation purposes, it may be registered at a Utah Division of Motor Vehicles Office as an implement of husbandry and will be exempt from these regulations.
To be a "street-legal type I or type II ATV", the following must be met:
The operator must meet the same requirements as a motorcycle in that:
The vehicle must be driven so as to follow all traffic rules;
The operator must be at least sixteen years of age and possess a valid driver's license in accordance with the Utah Uniform Driver License Act;
The vehicle must be legally registered and possess a state issued license plate;
The owner must pay fees in lieu of property taxes;
The vehicle must meet the following requirements as a motor vehicle, in that:
The vehicle must be covered by motor vehicle insurance and proof thereof must be carried in/on the vehicle;
The vehicle must pass vehicle emissions inspection;
The vehicle must pass a safety inspection.
To be a "street-legal ATV" the following equipment is required:
Headlamps;
One or more tail lamp;
Light illuminating the license plate;
Red reflectors to the rear;
Stop lamps on the rear;
Amber electric turn signals front and rear;
A breaking system, other than a parking break;
A horn or other warning device;
A muffler and emissions control system;
Rear view mirrors on both sides of the vehicle;
A windshield, or eye protection for the driver;
An illuminated speedometer;
A footrest and handhold for each passenger; and,
For "side by side" vehicles, a seatbelt for each occupant.
The operator of a "street-legal ATV" may not exceed the posted speed limit or a maximum speed of forty-five miles per hour.
HMC (Ord. No. 2010-12, § 2(Exh. A), 7-20-2012)

HISTORY
Renumbered by Ord. O-2020-25 on 8/18/2020
10.08.090 Prohibition; Parking Of Trailers And Inoperable Vehicles On City-Owned Parking Spaces
It shall be unlawful for any person or owner to leave, park, station, or allow it to be parked or abandoned any unattended, inoperable, or unregistered motor vehicle or trailer in any city-owned parking spaces (town center, parks, public buildings, etc.) unless otherwise designated and signed. Attended and registered trailers may be parked for a period not to exceed twenty-four hours. A first violation of this section is punishable by an infraction. A subsequent violation of this section is punishable by a Class "C" misdemeanor. Any motor vehicle or trailer which is parked in violation of this section may be removed by the city or its designee at the owner's expense.
HISTORY
Adopted by Ord. O-2015-01 on 3/17/2015
Amended by Ord. O-2018-04 on 2/20/2018
Renumbered by Ord. O-2020-25 on 8/18/2020
10.08.100 Impeding Or Blocking Traffic; Violation; Penalty
It is unlawful for any person to engage in conduct that may impede or block traffic within any of the areas described below under the jurisdiction of or within the boundaries of Highland City, including all associated shoulder areas, on-ramps, off-ramps, and areas between the roadways of a divided highway:
an interstate system, as defined in Utah Code Section 72-1-102;
a freeway, as defined in Utah Code Section 41-6a-102;
a state highway, as defined in Utah Code Title 72, Chapter 4, Designation of State Highways Act;
a state route, or "SR," as defined in Utah Code Section 72-1-102; or
any other highway that:
is paved and has a speed limit of 35 miles per hour or higher;
has a median, whether elevated or flat; or
has a fixed guideway as defined in Utah Code Section 59-12-102 or any other railway that shares the highway right-of-way.
Conduct that may impede or block traffic includes:
while a pedestrian, accepting, transacting, exchanging, or otherwise taking possession or control of money or property from a person within a  motor vehicle while that motor vehicle is within a highway;
while a driver or passenger of a motor vehicle within a highway, accepting, transacting, exchanging, or otherwise taking possession or control of money or property from a pedestrian.
Conduct that impedes or blocks traffic under this section does not include:
conduct or actions to comply with a lawful order or direction of a peace officer, firefighter, flagger at a construction or maintenance site, or uniformed adult school crossing guard;
conduct or actions resulting from a traffic accident, medical emergency, or similar exigent circumstance, including exchanging insurance or contact information;
conduct or actions that occur while the motor vehicle is legally parked; or
conduct or actions that are located entirely on a sidewalk.
A violation of this section is an infraction.


HISTORY
Adopted by Ord. O-2020-27 on 9/1/2020
Chapter 10.09 PARKING OF COMMERCIAL VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL ZONES
10.09.010 Definitions
10.09.020 Prohibition
10.09.030 Limited Parking Of Commercial Vehicles
10.09.040 Grandfathered Exceptions
10.09.050 Construction Vehicle Exceptions
10.09.060 Home Occupations
10.09.070 Parking In The Street
10.09.100 Penalty

10.09.010 Definitions
"Commercial vehicle" for purposes of this chapter shall mean any vehicle, trailer or construction equipment which is primarily used in a trade or business, which bears any logo or other advertisement of a trade or business, or which is actually being used in a trade or business.

HMC (Ord. 1998-13 § 1(part))
10.09.020 Prohibition
In keeping with the residential nature of residential zones, parking shall be a permitted use only as an accessory use to serve the main building or use on the property. No parking of commercial vehicles in residential zones is allowed except as set forth in this chapter.

HMC (Ord. 1998-13 § 1(part))
10.09.030 Limited Parking Of Commercial Vehicles
Parking of commercial vehicles in residential zones shall be limited to one commercial vehicle not to exceed a one-ton chassis per lot.

HMC (Ord. 1998-13 § 1(part))
10.09.040 Grandfathered Exceptions
Any person who was parking or storing an operational commercial vehicle in a residential zone in Highland City on or before January 1, 1998, (excepted commercial vehicle), may continue to park or store that excepted commercial vehicle subject to the following conditions:

All excepted commercial vehicles must be parked behind the front line of the home.
No exception shall be granted for parking on any lot which is less than forty thousand square feet in area.
Any exception shall be discontinued upon any change in the primary resident ownership of the property at which the vehicles have been parked or stored.
These foregoing exceptions shall only apply if the vehicle owner requests and receives an exception permit for each excepted commercial vehicle prior to December 31, 1998.
HMC (Ord. 1998-13 § 1(part))

10.09.050 Construction Vehicle Exceptions
Construction, contracting or earth-moving equipment which are otherwise classified as commercial vehicles may be temporarily parked or stored on real property provided the vehicles are actively being used for construction activities on the specific property where the vehicles are being parked or stored.

HMC (Ord. 1998-13 § 1(part))
10.09.060 Home Occupations
All vehicles associated with a home occupation must comply with the home occupation ordinance and permit. Employees of a resident shall not park commercial vehicles on the resident's lot.

HMC (Ord. 1998-13 § 1(part))
10.09.070 Parking In The Street
Nothing in this chapter shall detract from the ordinances governing parking in the public rights-of-way.

HMC (Ord. 1998-13 § 1(part))
10.09.100 Penalty
Any violation of this chapter shall be punished as a class B misdemeanor.

HMC (Ord. 1998-13 § 1(part))
Chapter 10.12 PARKING REGULATIONS
10.12.010 Parking Prohibited
10.12.020 Parking Regulations; Sign Placement
10.12.030 Signs And Markings
10.12.040 Violation; Penalties

10.12.010 Parking Prohibited
"Vehicle" is defined to include, but not necessarily be limited to, automobiles, trucks, trailers, mobile homes, travel trailers, boats, motorcycles, buses, snowmobiles, and other objects used or capable of being used for transportation purposes whether for the transport of humans, animals or freight of any kind.
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on a street in violation of the restrictions as posted on any signs or other traffic control devices thereby restricting parking.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-15, § 1, 7-6-2011)

10.12.020 Parking Regulations; Sign Placement
The city upon obtaining the prior approval of the city council may place signs prohibiting or restricting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles on any street or highway where after it is determined that such stopping, standing or parking would unduly interfere with the free movement of traffic thereof. Such signs as placed by the city shall be official signs, and no person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle in violation of the restrictions stated on such signs.
No person shall without the permission of the city place or cause to be placed on any street or sidewalk or on any building any sign preventing or forbidding the parking of vehicles in the street in front of any building or place of business.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-15, § 1, 7-6-2011)

10.12.030 Signs And Markings
The city engineer, subject to prior approval of the mayor, is authorized subject to provisions and limitations of this code and after an adequate study, to place, and when required in this chapter, shall place and maintain appropriate signs or traffic markings to indicate standing or parking regulations. Traffic markings designating zones shall have the meanings set forth in this subsection:
"Red" shall mean no stopping or parking at any time.
"Yellow" shall be a twenty minute loading zone.
"Blue" shall mean handicapped parking only.
When appropriate signs or traffic curb markings have been erected or placed according to this section, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any zone in violation of any of the provisions of this section.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-15, § 1, 7-6-2011)

10.12.040 Violation; Penalties
A violation of HMC 10 is punishable by an infraction.
Upon discretion of the chief of police, or his or her agent, the vehicle may be impounded.
HMC (Ord. No. 2011-15, § 1, 7-6-2011)

Chapter 12.02 FREE EXPRESSION REGULATION
It is the declared public policy of Highland City that persons and groups have a right to organize and participate in peaceful expressive activities including demonstrations, rallies, parades, signature gathering, marches, picketing or other similar actions conducted for the purpose of persons expressing their political, social, religious, or other views, and to do so on the public grounds of the City, as defined herein, near the object of their protest or action so they may be seen and heard, subject to reasonable restrictions designed to protect public safety, persons, and property and to accommodate the interests of persons not participating in the assemblies, including their interests in using the streets and sidewalks to travel to their intended destinations, and to use the parks and park facilities for recreational purposes. 
In accordance with Utah Code §11-61-104, Highland City shall only impose a generally applicable time, place, and manner restriction on expressive activity on public grounds by ordinance or by policy or practice that comports with this Section.
For purposes of this Section:
"Public grounds” means the area outside of a public building, as that term is defined in Utah Code Section 11-61-102(5), that is a traditional public forum where members of the public may safely gather to engage in expressive activity.
“Public grounds” do not include:
the interior of a public building; or
any public property that is not a traditional public forum, such as, but not limited to, sidewalks constructed primarily to assist patrons to negotiate the space between the parking lot and the door, and not to facilitate the daily commerce and life of the neighborhood, and other areas as defined in accordance with the rulings of the United States Supreme Court.
“Traditional public forum” refers to: a public park or street, or a public sidewalk, as defined by the United States Supreme Court, or as that Court may later define it.
In accordance with Utah Code Section 11-61-103, this Section does not apply to:
A restriction on expressive activity on public grounds that is imposed in order to comply with Utah Code Title 20A Election Code;
Property that Highland owns or leases that is closed to public access or where state or federal law restricts expressive activity; or
A limited or nonpublic forum.
A generally applicable or individually applicable time, place, and manner restriction on expressive activity on public grounds imposed by ordinance, policy, or practice must comport with state law, constitutional law, and case law, and, in accordance with Utah Code Section 11-61-104, must be:
Narrowly tailored to serve an important governmental interest, including public access to the public building, public safety, and protection of public property;
Unrelated to the suppression of a particular message or the content of the expressive activity that the restriction addresses; and
Leave open reasonable alternative means for the expressive activity.
This ordinance is not intended to infringe on the rights individuals have to use public forums in accordance with state law. 
HISTORY
Adopted by Ord. O-2019-06 on 5/7/2019

12.04.010 Culverts And Boxes Over Ditches
It is unlawful for any person to convey water across any sidewalk within the limits of Highland except in a covered culvert or box extending the whole width of the sidewalk; it shall likewise be unlawful for any person to use or maintain any such culvert or box without keeping the same in good repair and cleared of debris.

HMC (Ord. 1982-7 § 7-1)
12.04.020 Discharging Water On Streets Or Sidewalks
It is unlawful for any person owning, occupying or having control of any premises to suffer or permit water from the roof or eaves of any house, building or other structure, or from any other source under the control of such person, to be discharged and spread upon the surface of any street or sidewalk.

HMC (Ord. 1982-7 § 7-2)
12.04.030 Penalty For Discharging Water On Streets Or Sidewalks
Every person who wilfully or negligently obstructs, injures or floods any street or sidewalk by the flow or seepage of water, or who wilfully or negligently permits water under his control to escape in any manner so as to obstruct, injure or flood any street or sidewalk within the limits of this city, is guilty of a misdemeanor.

HMC (Ord. 1982-7 § 7-3)
12.04.040 Building Materials In Street Permit
It is unlawful for any person to occupy or use any portion of the public streets when erecting or repairing any building upon land abutting thereon, without first making application to and receiving from the city council a permit for the occupation or use of such portions of streets for such periods of time and under such limitations and restrictions as may be required by the city council. Any such permit may be revoked by the city council at any time when the holder thereof fails to comply with any rule or regulation under which it is granted, or when, in the opinion of the city council, the public interest requires such revocation.

HMC (Ord. 1999-8 § 1(part))
12.04.050 Provision Of Sanitary Facilities And Curb Ramps
It is unlawful for any person who is constructing any new structure, building or residence to build such structure, building, or residence without sanitary toilet facilities available to those working on the site. Once a lavatory is installed, inspected, and available to workers, a portable toilet may be removed. Such lavatory shall be placed in an inconspicuous place as possible.
All persons participating in the above named construction shall provide access to the site where curbs are installed. It is unlawful for any person to provide access other than through the use of curb ramps or through the use of three-fourth inch washed gravel. All curb ramps or gravel approaches must be removed prior to final inspection to the satisfaction of the city.
HMC (Ord. 1999-18)

12.04.060 Placing Trash Or Other Obstruction In Streets, Gutters And Sidewalks
It is unlawful for any developer of subdivisions, contractor, builder or person owning, occupying or having control of any premises to place, or permit to be placed upon or in the sidewalk, parking area, gutter, or on the half of the street next to such premises or to fail to remove from the streets, gutters, or sidewalks:

Any construction materials, broken ware, glass, filth, rubbish, sweepings, refuse matter, ice, snow, water, garbage, ashes, tin cans or other like substances;
Any vehicles, trailers, lumber, wood boxes, fencing, building material, dead trees, tree stumps, merchandise or other thing which shall obstruct such public street, gutter, parking area or sidewalk, or any part thereof, except as expressly authorized by ordinance, without first obtaining the permission of the city council.
Any permanent or temporary structure, mechanism, device, vehicle, or other thing of any kind or character except trees planted pursuant to the provisions of applicable ordinance.
It is unlawful for any developer, landscaper, contractor, property owner, or any person owning, occupying or having control of any premises to place, or permit to be placed upon or in the sidewalk, gutter, or any part of the street or right-of-way any dirt, mud, soil, rocks or any landscaping material.
HMC (Ord. 1999-8 § 1(part); Ord. 2005-36 (part))

12.04.065 Use Of Trash Containers, Site Cleanup And Unlawful Use Of Nonsite Trash Containers
It is unlawful for any person who is constructing any new structure, building or residence to build such structure, building or residence without having on the premises a trash container sufficiently sized to accommodate construction debris and trash which results from such construction. It shall be the duty of the general contractor and absent a general contractor, the owner of the building permit to keep such site free of debris at all times. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit trash in a construction dumpster without express permission of the general contractor or the owner of the building permit.

HMC (Ord. 1999-8 § 1(part))
12.04.070 Building Official Enforcement
The building official is not permitted to perform a building inspection if in his/or her opinion the site is not in conformance with any aspect of this chapter.

HMC (Ord. 1999-8 § 1(part))
12.04.080 Penalty For Violation Of This Chapter
Any person in violation of any part of this chapter shall be guilty of a Class B misdemeanor. The minimum fine for any of these offenses (exception of Section 12.04.060(D) of this chapter) shall be two hundred dollars. The minimum fine for a violation of Section 12.04.060(D) shall be five hundred dollars for each offense. The responsible party shall remove/clean all mud, dirt, debris or specified material from any right-of-way or public property within twenty-four hours of the violation after being notified. The city may at its discretion clean or have cleaned or removed any mud, dirt, debris or similar material from any portion of a right-of-way or public property immediately following any notification to the responsible party. All costs incurred by the city to clean any tracked mud, dirt, debris or similar materials will be passed on to the responsible party. The fine for tracking mud, dirt, debris or similar materials onto a right-of-way may be taken from the bond associated with a building permit. The enforcement of this section shall apply immediately following the issuance of a building permit.

HMC (Ord. 1999-8 § 1(part); Ord. 2005-36 (part))
12.04.090 Parking
A person or person(s) that may be involved in any construction or development project in Highland City may not cause mud, dirt, debris or any similar material to cross the property line on which the construction or project is occurring. Vehicles and trailers associated with home construction in Highland City shall park on an improved street adjacent to the property under construction and shall not park upon that property or cross the curb connected with that property. Construction trailers or vehicles may not be parked within the public right-of-way between the hours of eleven p.m. and six a.m. A vehicle or trailer may only be parked within property under construction if upon a concrete, asphalt or gravel driveway or parking area. Temporary driveways and parking areas shall be consistent with the minimum requirements of Highland City. A concrete driveway and drive approach for the property under construction consistent with the minimum requirements of the Highland City development code shall be required in all cases.

HMC (Ord. 2004-6 (part))
12.04.110 Staging Areas
Development of any property shall require a staging area for ingress/egress to limit the amount of dust and debris being tracked onto the public right-of-way. All construction traffic associated with each development shall use the staging area for parking and ingress/egress only. The staging area shall be constructed as illustrated within the Highland City development standards and public improvement specifications.

HMC (Ord. 2004-6 (part))
12.04.120 Washout Areas
If the development of property requires grading exceeding one acre in surface area, the developer shall construct a washout area immediately adjacent to the staging area to limit the amount of dust and debris being tracked onto the public right-of-way. Drivers of construction vehicles shall use this area to wash dirt or mud from their vehicle prior to entering the staging area and the public right-of-way. The washout area shall be constructed as illustrated within the Highland City development standards and public improvement specifications.

HMC (Ord. 2004-6 (part))
12.04.130 Dust And Mud Prevention Plan
The developer of property which requires grading which exceeds one acre in surface area or development of property which exceeds one acre in size shall submit to the city a dust and mud prevention plan. The dust and mud prevention plan shall include a sign as outlined within the Highland City development standards and public improvement specifications.

HMC (Ord. 2004-6 (part))
12.04.140 Enforcement
Any person who has parked their vehicle onto property in violation of this section after April 20, 2004 shall be cited where the violation has occurred. If any mud, dirt, debris or similar material has been dumped, placed, tracked or moved onto a right-of-way or public property, the person(s) who is primarily responsible (general contractor, property owner) for the violation shall be notified with the placement of a stop work order, contacted by phone, or contacted in person by any city official and shall have twenty-four hours to comply with this chapter.

HMC (Ord. 2004-6 (part); Ord. 2005-36 (part))
12.04.150 Penalty
The violation: Any person who has parked their vehicle onto property under construction in violation of this section shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor. The minimum fine for this offense shall be two hundred dollars. Any person(s) who has tracked mud, dirt, debris or similar material onto a public right-of-way or public property shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor. The minimum fine for each offense shall be five hundred dollars. The responsible party shall remove/clean all mud, dirt, debris or specified material from any right-of-way or public property within twenty-four hours of the violation after being notified. If the responsible party has been previously notified of this ordinance the city shall issue a citation when this ordinance is violated immediately upon evidence of each occurrence. The city may at its discretion clean or have cleaned or removed any mud, dirt, debris or similar material from any portion of a right-of-way or public property immediately following any notification to the responsible party. All costs incurred by the city to clean any tracked mud, dirt, debris or similar materials will be passed on to the responsible party. The fine for tracking mud, dirt, debris or similar materials onto a right-of-way may be taken from the bond associated with a building permit. The enforcement of this section shall apply immediately following the issuance of a building permit.

Chapter 12.08 ROAD MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR
12.08.010 Purpose
12.08.020 Road Maintenance Map
