13.44.018 Satellite Dishes
13.44.020 Wind Conversion
13.44.022 Solar Equipment
13.44.024 Wireless Telecommunications Facilities
13.44.026 Telecommunication Facility Justification Study And Master Plan Required
13.44.028 Master Plan Requirements
13.44.030 Telecommunication Facility Justification Study Requirements
13.44.032 Permitted Uses
13.44.034 Technical Necessity Exception/conditional Uses
13.44.036 Equipment Facilities
13.44.038 Historic Sites
13.44.040 Antennas Not Permitted
13.44.042 Business License Requirement
13.44.044 Non-Maintained Or Abandoned Facilities
13.44.046 Building Permits
13.44.048 Wireless Telecommunications Facilities Illustrations

13.44.010 Summary; Purpose Of Provisions
This chapter addresses planning issues resulting from the rapid growth in demand for low power radio services. This chapter distinguishes low power radio services from other broadcasting type telecommunication technologies and establishes provisions that deal with issues of demand, visual mitigation, noise, engineering, residential impacts, health, safety and facility siting. It is the intent of this provision to protect the aesthetic viewshed within Highland City, to promote more antennas that use stealth design and technology, and to specifically restrict monopoles with typical array antenna construction wherever possible.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.012 Application
The requirements of this chapter apply to both commercial and private low power radio services such as cellular or PCS (personal communications system), communications and paging systems. All facilities shall comply with the following regulations and all other ordinances of the city and any pertinent regulations of the Federal Communications Commission and the Federal Aviation Administration.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.014 Definitions
The following definitions are specific to this chapter.

"Antenna" means any system of wires, poles, rods, arms, reflecting discs or similar devices of various sizes, materials, and shapes including but not limited to solid or wire-mesh dish, horn, spherical or bar configuration used for the transmission or reception of radio signals. Types of antennas include:

Roof Mounted Antenna. An antenna or series of individual antennas mounted directly to a flat roof of a building, mechanical penthouse or parapet enclosure wall which is on the roof top of a building.
Top-hat Antenna. A spatial array of antennas, generally located on a free-standing structure, where the visible width of antennas and antenna mounting structures are more than two feet in width as viewed looking directly at the structure.
Utility Pole Antennas. Any antenna mounted directly to a street light pole. This definition shall not include poles carrying electrical lines, telephone lines or any other type of utility not specifically included above.
Wall Mounted Antenna. Any antenna or series of individual antennas mounted directly to the fascia or outside vertical wall of a structure, existing parapet walls, penthouses, or mechanical equipment rooms, with no portion of the antenna extending above the roofline of such structures.
Whip Antenna. An antenna that is cylindrical in shape. Whip antennas can be directional or omni-directional and vary in size depending upon the frequency and gain for which they are designed.
"Antenna support structure" means a structure the principle purpose of which is for location of antennas. Types of antenna support structures include:

Monopole. A free standing antenna support structure placed directly on the ground used to support one or more antennas.
Lattice Tower. A self-supporting multiple sided, open steel frame structure used to support one or more antennas.
"Co-location" means a telecommunications facility comprising more than one telecommunications provider's antennas.

"Equipment facility" means any building, shelter or cabinet used by telecommunication providers to house switching, backup or other equipment at a telecommunications facility.

"Lattice tower" means a self-supporting multiple sides, open steel frame structure used to support telecommunications equipment.

"Low power radio services facility" means an unmanned structure which consists of equipment used primarily for the transmission, reception or transfer of voice or data through radio wave or wireless transmissions. Such sites typically require the construction of transmission support structures to which antenna equipment is attached.

"Monopole" means a single cylindrical antenna support structure that acts as a support structure for antennas.

"Monopole with antennas and antenna support structure greater than two feet in width" means a self-supporting monopole tower on which antennas or antenna support structures exceeding two feet in diameter from the center of the pole are placed. The antennas and antenna support structures may not exceed thirteen feet in width or eight feet in height.

"Monopole with antennas and antenna support structure less than two feet in width" means a self-supporting monopole tower on which antennae or antenna support structures not exceeding two feet in width are placed. Antennas and antenna support structures may not exceed ten feet in height.

"Non-stealth design" means any antenna or equipment facility not camouflaged in a manner to blend with surrounding land uses, features or architecture. The design does not conceal the intended use of the telecommunications facility. A monopole with equipment facilities above ground and unscreened would be considered non-stealth. An antenna with a top hat or triangle array exceeding two feet in diameter from the center of pole would be considered non-stealth.

"Residential institutional use" means a school, church, clubhouse or public building in a residential zone. This definition does not include residences or multi-family structures containing one or more residential units.

"Stealth" means antennas, antenna support structures and equipment facilities camouflaged or designed to blend with surrounding land uses, features, and architecture, thus minimizing the aesthetic impact on adjacent uses, thereby concealing the intended use and appearance of the telecommunications facility such as heavy landscaping, installing telecommunications facilities within existing buildings, or placing equipment facilities underground. The following uses shall be considered as stealth antennas:

Wall Mount Antenna. A flush wall mount antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
The antenna is painted the same color as the background; and
The antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located inside; and
The antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located within an enclosed structure attached the building it is located on if the attached structure meets all zoning regulations and is designed to be architecturally consistent with the building where it is attached.
Flag Pole Antenna. A flag pole antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
A pole with all antennae and their associative supportive structure and power supply cables hidden entirely within the inside of the pole; and
A pole that is bronze in material or color, or a pole that is painted to blend with the visual surroundings; and
A pole that has a maximum radius at grade of two feet and a maximum radius at peak of twelve inches; and
A pole that includes an American flag in proportion to the flag pole height; and
The associative equipment is less than twelve cubic feet in size, maximum of three feet in height and landscaped or located within an adjacent building; and
A pole that includes a cap at peak typically associated with a flag pole; and
A pole that includes lighting for the American flag that is illuminated moderately and subdued according to the surrounding uses.
Dormer Antenna. A dormer antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
The antenna is designed to be architecturally consistent with the existing building the antenna will be located on; and
The dormer does not project above the roofline of the building it is located on; and
The antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located inside; and
The antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located within an enclosed structure attached the building it is located on if the attached structure meets all zoning regulations and is designed to be architecturally consistent with the building where it is attached.
Chimney Antenna. A chimney antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
The antenna is designed to be architecturally consistent with the existing building the antenna will be located on; and
The chimney does not project more than three feet above the roofline of the building it is located on; and
The antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located inside; and
The antenna is located on a building where the equipment facility is located within an enclosed structure attached the building it is located on if the attached structure meets all zoning regulations and is designed to be architecturally consistent with the building where it is attached.
Landscape Antenna. A landscape antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
The antenna is designed to be consistent in height, shape and color with the local biome or geographically surrounding and immediately adjacent environment (rocks, trees) where the antenna will be located; and
The area around the base of the antenna is re-vegetated with native planting; and
The associated equipment is camouflaged similar to the antenna or buried.
Light Pole Antenna. A light pole antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
A pole that is located within a city park and adjacent to a sport field with additionally planned or constructed light poles; and
A pole with all antennae and their associative supportive structure and power supply cables hidden entirely within the inside of the pole; and
A pole that is consistent in material to adjacent light poles within the same park; and
A pole that has a maximum radius at grade of 2 feet and a maximum radius at peak of twelve inches; and
A pole that includes lighting facilities approved by the city consistent with park lighting and sufficient for the use intended; and
The associative equipment is less than 12 cubic feet in size, maximum of 3 feet in height and landscaped or located within an existing park facility building; and
The applicant increases the size of a pavilion, restroom, or other similar park facility if the equipment requires a larger facility if the new facility meets all zoning and other city requirements associated with a park or the modified structure.
Truss Antenna. A truss antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
The antenna is located entirely within the roof of an existing building; and
The antenna does not project outside of the building it is located within; and
The antenna is located within a building where the equipment facility is located inside; and
The antenna is located within a building where the equipment facility is located within an enclosed structure attached the building it is located on if the attached structure meets all zoning regulations and is designed to be architecturally consistent with the building where it is attached.
High Power Transmission Line Antenna. A high power transmission line antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
The pole shall be considered a high power transmission line carrier for the local power company and shall be constructed of galvanized metal and painted to blend as much as possible with the surroundings; and
A pole with all associative supportive structure and power supply cables hidden entirely within the inside of the pole; and
A pole that is painted to blend with the visual surroundings; and
All antennas shall be less than 18 inches from the surface of the pole; and
The associative equipment is less than 12 cubic feet in size, maximum of 3 feet in height and landscaped, or buried, or located within an adjacent building.
Co-location Antenna. A high power transmission line antenna shall be considered stealth if it includes the following features:
The original initial installation received a conditional use permit; and
The new facility shall comply with all other provisions relating to site development, landscaping, security etc., as provided herein and the conditions required for the original facility; and
The new antennas and antenna structure shall not exceed eighteen inches from the surface of the existing monopole; and
The equipment for the new antenna shall be enclosed within a masonry shelter or an existing building; and
The new antenna wiring conduit and power supply shall not be exposed above the roofline of the new or existing structure.
"Telecommunications facility" means an unmanned structure which consists of equipment, including antennas, antenna support structures and equipment facilities as defined herein, that transmit and/or receive voice and/or data communications through radio signals such as "cellular" or "PCS" (personal communications system) communications and paging systems.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.016 Special Antennas And Energy Equipment
Special antennas and energy equipment shall include satellite dishes, wind power conversion facilities, and solar power facilities.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.018 Satellite Dishes
Earth Station. Any apparatus or device, commonly known as an earth terminal antennae, earth terminal, satellite communication antennae, satellite antennae, microwave dish antennae, satellite television antennae, or dish antennae, which is designed for the purpose of transmitting and/or receiving radio, television, satellite, microwave, or other electromagnetic energy signals, but does not include conventional television, radio, and amateur radio antennae. Earth Station regulations shall apply to Earth Stations with a dish diameter over four feet in size. Earth Stations with a dish diameter under four feet in size shall be regulated in the same manner as television antennas.
Location of Earth Stations, over four feet in diameter, in residential zones.
Ground Mounted in all Residential Zones:
Maximum Height. Maximum height from grade to the top of the dish shall be twelve feet. Any ground mounted Earth Station with a height exceeding twelve feet shall be allowed only with a conditional use approval from the planning commission.
Number per Lot. A maximum of one Earth Station structure shall exist at any one time on any residentially zoned property.
Front Yard. If there is no other alternative for the location, Earth Stations may be allowed in the front yard area only with a conditional use approval from the planning commission.
Setback maximums from the public street shall be determined by the planning commission, and
Applicants shall provide a site plan indicating the location of the Earth Station.
Rear and Side Yards. Earth Stations shall be located in rear yards, where possible. If rear yards are not acceptable for proper reception of signals, the Earth Station may be located in either side yard.
On corner lots, the Earth Station may be situated to the rear of the main dwelling and within the area between the main building and street when approved by the planning commission as a conditional use.
Easements, Rights-of-Way. No Earth Station shall be located on any legally recorded public utility easement or right-of-way.
Multi-Family. One Earth Station shall be allowed per building. A second Earth Station may be allowed with a conditional use approval from the planning commission.

Roof Mounted in all Residential Zones:
Approval. If the rear and side yards are deemed unacceptable for suitable signal reception, then roof mounted Earth Stations may be permitted with a conditional use review and approval from the planning commission. Such roof installations may be permitted by the planning commission under the following criteria:
Roof mounted Earth Stations shall be mounted directly upon the roof of a primary structure, and shall not be mounted upon appurtenances such as chimneys, towers, trees, poles, or spires.
An Earth Station shall not exceed a height determined appropriate by the planning commission. The height of the structure shall not exceed the maximum height limits established within the zone in which the Earth Station is to be located.
Evidence of wind loading and structural safety of the Earth Station shall be provided to the planning commission by the applicants.
An Earth Station mounted on a roof shall be located on the portion of the roof which is oriented to the rear yard rather than located on the portion of the roof visible from the street.
Location of Earth Stations, over four feet in diameter, in commercial and industrial zones.
Ground Mounted in Commercial and Industrial Zones:
Maximum Height. Maximum height from grade to the top of the dish shall be fifteen feet. Any Earth Station with a height exceeding fifteen feet shall be allowed only with a conditional use approval from the planning commission.
Number Allowed. Two Earth Station structures shall be permitted at any one time per separate commercial or industrial business. More than two Earth Stations may be permitted with a conditional use approval from the planning commission.
Advertising. No Earth Station shall display lettering or numbers for advertising purposes.
Rear and Side Yards. An Earth Station in any commercial or industrial shall be located in the rear or side yard area, if possible.
Front Yards. An Earth Station may be located in the front yard provided the structure is not located in the minimum front landscape area, and the structure does not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic.
Easements, Rights-of-Way. No Earth Station shall be located on any legally recorded public utility easement or right-of-way.
Roof Mounted in all Commercial and Industrial Zones:
Approval. If the front, rear, and side yards are deemed unacceptable for suitable signal reception, or pose a negative aesthetic or neighborhood impact, then roof mounted Earth Stations may be permitted with conditional use review and approval from the planning commission. Such roof installations may be permitted under the following criteria:
Roof mounted Earth Stations shall be mounted directly upon the roof of a primary structure, and shall not be mounted upon appurtenances such as chimneys, towers, trees, poles which exceed the minimum height of mast required to mount the antennae to the roof, spires, or similar structures.
The height of a roof mounted Earth Station located in any commercial or industrial shall not exceed twelve feet above the highest point of the roof upon which the structure is located. Height increases over twelve feet may be approved by the planning commission as deemed appropriate. The roof mounted Earth Station shall not exceed the maximum height limits established within the zone in which the Earth Station is to be located.
Other criteria as deemed appropriate by the planning commission.
All roof mounted Earth Stations shall be screened from view from adjacent streets and properties in the same manner as is required of all other roof mounted equipment in this development code. Said station shall not significantly change the architectural character of the structure.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.020 Wind Conversion
Wind energy conversion systems shall meet the following standards:

Minimum tower setback from any property line shall equal the height of the tower.
Towers shall meet main dwelling setbacks for the particular zone in which the tower is located.
There shall be sufficient safety measures to prevent the tower from becoming a climbing hazard.
The tower shall not be located on a utility easement or right-of-way.
In the case of joint ownership of a tower, the structure may be located on any lot(s) as approved by the chief building official, providing the tower meets setback requirements mentioned above in respect to all perimeter properties.
The owner shall obtain a building permit and certification by a registered engineer as to the safety of equipment and installation.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.022 Solar Equipment
These regulations shall apply to all solar heating developments, private or public, to the extent that design review is not preempted by state or federal law.

Review and Standards. All applications for building permits for structures with solar installations shall be forwarded to the community development department for review and approval. The proposed installation will be reviewed to assure compliance with the following standards:
Collectors shall not reflect sunlight into neighboring windows.
The installation shall extend no higher than roof ridge line, or on a flat roof, a parapet wall.
The installation shall stand no more than seven feet above the surface of the roof.
The color of collector frames shall be compatible with the roof.
The piping shall blend with the surface to which it is attached.
The ends of the panel arrays shall be covered and mounting brackets shall blend with the roof and not be visible from front yard.
Planning Commission Review.
If a review by the planning commission is considered necessary, the development shall be reviewed at a regularly scheduled meeting. At the time of the meeting the applicant shall provide the following:
Site plan.
Drawings showing existing building elevations.
Landscaping and screening plans.
The kind, color and texture of materials to be used.
Any other pertinent information determined to be necessary by the director.
the planning commission shall approve, approve with conditions, or deny the development or structure.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.024 Wireless Telecommunications Facilities
Facility Types. Low power radio services facilities are characterized by the type or location of the antenna structure. There are five general types of such antenna structures: Wall mounted antennas; roof mounted antennas; monopoles with antennas and antenna support structure less than two feet in width; monopoles with antennas and antenna support structures greater than two feet in width; and lattice towers. A combination of both roof and wall mounted antennas are allowed on a building. The total area for all wall and roof mounted antennas and supporting structures combined shall not exceed forty square feet for each exterior wall of the building or a total of one hundred sixty square feet per building per carrier. A maximum of four walls shall be occupied by cellular antennas. The total area is the sum of the area of each individual antenna face and the visible portion of the supporting structure as viewed when looking directly at the face of the building. The total area for a roof mounted antenna shall apply to the closest exterior wall. Up to three carriers may utilize each building side for a maximum of four sides. Each carrier must obtain a separate conditional use permit. In no event will wall mounted antennas be allowed on the front of buildings. Monopoles with antennas and antenna support structure less than two feet in width and monopoles with antennas and antenna support structure greater than two feet in width, shall be allowed only in the rear yard area. These structures shall not be located in a required landscaped area, buffer area or required parking area. Standards for the installation of each type of antenna are as follows:

Wall Mounted Antenna. The following provisions apply to wall mounted antennas:
Wall mounted antennas shall not extend above the wall line of the building and shall not extend more than four feet horizontally from the face of the building.
Antennas, equipment and the supporting structures shall be painted to match the color of the building or structure or the background against which they are most commonly seen. Antennas and the supporting structures on buildings should be architecturally compatible with the building. Whip antennas are not allowed on a wall mounted antenna structure.
Antennas mounted directly on existing parapet walls, penthouses, or mechanical equipment rooms, with no portion of the antenna extending above the roof line of such structures, shall be considered a wall mounted antenna.
Roof Mounted Antenna. The following provisions apply to roof mounted antennas:
Roof mounted antennas shall be allowed on top of existing penthouse or mechanical equipment room, the antennas shall be mounted at least five feet from the exterior wall of a building. For antennas mounted between five and ten feet from the exterior wall, the maximum height of a roof mounted antenna is directly proportional to the distance the antenna is set back from the exterior wall up to a maximum height of ten feet above the roof line of the building to which the antenna is attached. Antennas shall be mounted at least five feet behind a parapet wall. For antennas mounted between five and ten feet behind a parapet wall, the maximum height of the antenna is directly proportional to the distance the antenna is set back from the wall up to a maximum of ten feet as measured from the top of the parapet wall.
Roof mounted antennas are permitted only on a flat roof and shall be screened, constructed and/or colored to match the structure to which they are attached.
Monopole With Antennas and Antenna Support Structures Less Than Two Feet in Width. The total antenna structure mounted on a monopole shall not exceed two feet in width. The maximum height of such antenna shall not exceed ten feet in height. All monopoles shall be located a minimum distance equal to one and one-half times the height of the monopole from an existing legal building lot.
Monopole With Antennas and Antenna Support Structure Greater Than Two Feet in Width. The maximum visible dimensions of antennas and antenna mounting structures shall not exceed thirteen feet as viewed looking directly at the monopole at the same elevation as the antennas and antenna mounting structure. All monopoles shall be located a minimum distance equal to one and one-half times the height of the monopole from an existing legal building lot nor within two hundred feet of SR 92 and SR 74, as designated gateway thoroughfares of the city.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.026 Telecommunication Facility Justification Study And Master Plan Required
A master plan for each company shall be submitted. Additionally, a complete application and telecommunication facility justification study shall be submitted by each company for each proposed telecommunications facility. The telecommunication facility justification study and master plan shall be submitted to the community development department, which will provide a preliminary review. Upon completion of the community development department review, the telecommunication facility justification study and master plan will be scheduled with the development committee for approval (if permitted) or further review and recommendation to the planning commission (if conditional or technical necessity exception) together with a complete application.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.028 Master Plan Requirements
A master plan shall be completed by each company. The master plan shall show proposed locations of future telecommunication facilities and include the rationale for each potential telecommunication facility. Maps shall be utilized to graphically illustrate the coverage radius of each potential telecommunication facility.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.030 Telecommunication Facility Justification Study Requirements
A telecommunication facility justification study shall be completed for each telecommunication facility by the wireless provider.

Wireless Telecommunication Facility Review Committee (WTFRC). The applicant shall first submit a complete application for a wireless telecommunication facility to the community development director a minimum of two weeks prior to the next available development review committee meeting for a preliminary review by the WTFRC. The WTFRC shall consist of the city administrator, city engineer, and community development director. If the applicant has submitted all of the required information for a wireless telecommunications facility, and it does not require a technical necessity exception/conditional use, the WTFRC may grant approval for a proposed wireless telecommunication facility if the application is determined to qualify as a permitted use per this ordinance.
The WTFRC may require additional conditions if the proposed antenna or associated equipment shelter is exposed. The WTFRC may impose additional conditions on a permitted use consistent with a conditional use application such as landscaping.
Technical Exception Required. If it is determined that the proposed application requires a technical necessity/conditional use per the ordinance the applicant will be required to submit a new and complete application consistent with Section 13.44.034 and Chapter 4 Conditional Use Procedure Highland City Development Code prior to being placed on the planning commission for a public hearing and recommendation. The city council shall be the legislative body to consider any application considered a technical exception/conditional use.
The telecommunication facility justification study required from all applicants and for every application requesting a wireless telecommunication facility shall include the following information:
Rationale. The rationale for the selection of the proposed telecommunication facility in view of the relative merits of any feasible alternative telecommunication facilities within the search ring. The telecommunication facility justification study shall include a description of the telecommunication facility, a description of the telecommunications facilities proposed to be placed on the location with technical reasons for their design and efforts made to minimize impacts on the surrounding land uses, a listing of other telecommunication facilities within the search ring which were evaluated and a statement of reasons why the final location was chosen. Staff may request the search ring and propagation information for the proposed telecommunication facilities. The applicant shall justify that the telecommunications facilities comply with the Highland City General Plan, as well as the required setback, height and landscaping requirements of the zoning in which they are proposed to be located.
Co-location. The study shall also examine the potential for co-location at an existing or the proposed telecommunication facility. If co-location is not possible at an existing telecommunication facility or if the proposed new telecommunication facility is not available for co-location, then the applicant shall include a written explanation why co-location is not possible.
Height. The height of the antennas and antenna support structures shall be justified through a detailed written analysis that explains in non-technical terms the reasons why service cannot be effectively provided unless at the requested height. If the proposed telecommunication facility is a roof mount or wall mount the city may request that the study verify that the existing or proposed screening will screen from view all telecommunications facilities.
Equipment Facilities. The study must include a detailed, written explanation and analysis, not limited to fiscal reasons alone, of the potential for the equipment facilities to be either (1) located in an existing building or (2) designed using stealth design technology or other visual screening is utilized that readily conceals the appearance of the equipment facilities.
Visual Analysis. The applicant shall submit a visual analysis, which may include photo simulation, field mock up or other techniques, which identifies the potential for visual impacts of the proposed telecommunications facility. The analysis shall consider views from public areas (streets, parks, etc.) and from private residences. The analysis shall assess the cumulative impacts of the proposed telecommunications facility and other existing or approved telecommunications facilities in the area as provided by city staff, and shall identify all mitigation measures consistent with the technical aspects and requirements of the proposed telecommunications facility. All costs associated with this requirement are to be borne by the applicant.
Independent Review. The city may if it deems necessary, cause each telecommunications facility to be reviewed by a qualified radio frequency engineer. The purpose of the review is to determine if other locations are available to achieve an equivalent signal distribution and not significantly affect the operation of the telecommunications facility. Such a review may be required when an applicant indicates that no other acceptable location exists. The costs shall be borne by the applicant.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.032 Permitted Uses
The following telecommunications facilities are classified as permitted use. Any request for telecommunications facilities differing from the standards as allowed in this section shall require a technical necessity exception from the planning commission and city council. All telecommunications facilities must comply with the Highland City General Plan, as well as the required setback, height and landscaping requirements of the zone in which they are to be located, and are subject to all provisions for "Site Plan Review," including modifications to existing site plans. All permitted use equipment facilities listed in this section must be (1) located inside of an existing building or (2) designed using stealth design technology or other visual screening is utilized that readily conceals the appearance of the equipment facilities.

City Property. Telecommunications facilities located on Highland City-owned property are allowed as a permitted use, provided the facilities meet the standards as specified for each type of facility as contained in this section and the facility owner has entered into a lease-type agreement with the city.
Wall Mounted Antenna. Wall mounted antennas which comply with the following standards are allowed as a permitted use:
Locations. Located on a parcel in a commercial, municipal, or professional office zone on a commercial, municipal or office structure or in residential zones on residential institutional uses.
Mounting Method. Wall mounted antennas shall not extend above the wall line of the building or extend more than four feet horizontally from the face of the building.
Stealth Design. Antennas, equipment facilities and the antenna support structure shall be constructed with stealth design to match the color of the building or structure and to be architecturally compatible with the building or to match the color of the background against which they are most commonly seen.
Area Limitations. The wall mounted antenna shall comply with "Area Limitations for Wall and Roof Mounted Antennas."
Roof Mounted Antenna. Roof mounted antennas which comply with the following standards are permitted uses:
Locations. Located on a parcel in a commercial, municipal, or professional office zone on a commercial, municipal or office structure or in residential zones on residential institutional uses.
Mounting Location.
Roof mounted antennas may be located on top of existing penthouses or mechanical equipment rooms provided the telecommunications facilities are enclosed by a structure that creates a visual screen. The screening structure and telecommunications facilities shall not extend more than eight feet above the existing roofline of the penthouse or mechanical equipment room.
For roof mounted antennas not mounted on a penthouse or mechanical equipment room, the telecommunications facilities shall be mounted at least five feet from any exterior wall of a building. For antennas mounted between five and ten feet from the exterior wall, the maximum height of a roof mounted antenna is directly proportional to the distance the antenna is set back from the exterior wall up to a maximum height of ten feet above the roofline of the building to which the antenna is attached.
Telecommunications facilities shall be mounted at least five feet behind any parapet wall. For antennas mounted between five and ten feet behind a parapet wall, the maximum height of the antenna is directly proportional to the distance the antenna is set back from the wall up to a maximum of ten feet as measured from the top of the parapet wall.
Screening. Roof mounted telecommunications facilities shall be located only on a flat roof and shall be screened, constructed and/or colored to match the structure to which they are attached.
Area Limitations for Wall and Roof Mounted Antennas. A combination of both roof and wall mounted antennas are allowed on a building. The total area for all wall and roof mounted antennas and antenna support structures combined shall not exceed forty square feet for each exterior wall of the building or a total of one hundred sixty square feet per building per carrier. A maximum of four walls may be occupied by antennas. The total area is the sum of the area of each individual antenna face and the visible portion of the antenna support structure and the equipment facility as viewed when looking directly at the face of the building. The total area for a roof mounted antenna shall apply to the closest exterior wall. Up to three carriers may utilize each building side for a maximum of four sides as a permitted use.
Co-location. Co-location of antennas on an existing monopole is a permitted use provided the antennas do not extend more than twelve inches from the monopole and meet all the provisions as stated in "Landscaping, Fencing and Safety" and "Equipment Facilities."
Stealth Design. Telecommunications facilities that incorporate stealth design technology as defined by this ordinance and are located on a parcel in a commercial or professional office zone or in a residential zone a on property of an existing residential institutional use or public open space or park property shall be considered as a permitted use.
Conversion. Conversion of flagpoles, light standards, athletic field lights or other similar structures, provided the structure's height is not increased more than ten feet, or the height is a maximum of forty feet for a new facility, shall be considered as a permitted use if the minimum specifications for these uses are met.
Flags and lighting facilities associated with conversion antennas shall be consistent in scale and material with the height and mass of the pole.
Lighting associated with conversion antennas shall not be installed to be directed toward existing residential property.
Lighting shall be entirely controlled and operated by the property owner of the ground the pole is located on (i.e. city, school).
All antennas and associated cables shall be installed entirely within the pole and buried underground.
Flag poles shall be capped with a typical ornament associated with flag poles at a scale consistent with the top of the pole.
Utility Pole Antennas. Utility pole antennas which comply with the following standards are permitted uses:
Location. Utility pole antennas may only be located on existing utility poles.
Method of Mounting. Such antennas shall be designed and installed by the applicant according to the city's specifications and details for utility poles.
Agreement. Consistent with the use of public rights of way by other utility and cable providers, each telecommunication provider is required to enter into an agreement with the city prior to installing any telecommunication facilities in the rights of way. The planning commission shall review site plan conditions prior to the execution of the agreement.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.034 Technical Necessity Exception/conditional Uses
If an applicant cannot meet the standards for telecommunications facilities as provided for in "Permitted Uses" for technical reasons, an applicant may request a technical necessity exception under the conditional use process. If an applicant cannot or will not meet those standards for reasons other than technical reasons the use is not allowed.

Telecommunications facilities which meet the following standards shall be considered for a technical necessity exception and shall be approved through the conditional use process:

Comply with the Highland City General Plan, as well as the required setback, height and landscaping requirements of the zoning in which they are located.
An applicant cannot meet the standards for telecommunication facilities as provided in "Permitted Uses" for technical reasons.
Monopoles are not allowed in any zone within the city without a technical necessity exception being granted by the city council through a conditional use process. Following are the minimum standards for a monopole to qualify for a technical necessity exception/conditional use. The planning commission and city council may impose additional requirements as defined in this ordinance. If the city is the property owner, the city may impose additional requirements at its discretion as part of a lease agreement between property owner and service provider.
Independent Review. All applications requesting a monopole under the technical necessity exception provision shall complete an independent radio frequency engineering review of the proposed monopole telecommunication facility in relation to the (1) requested height (2) alternative locations (3) other proposed telecommunication facilities and (4) existing telecommunication facilities within Highland City. The cost of the independent review shall be borne by the applicant.
Antenna Sizing. The maximum visible width of antennas and antenna support structures on a monopole shall not exceed eight feet in height or three feet in width as viewed looking directly at the monopole at same elevation as the antennas and antenna support structure and do not exceed a perpendicular distance of twenty-four inches from the surface of the pole. "Top Hat" design is not permitted.
Location and Minimum Setbacks. Monopoles shall be allowed only in the rear yard area of any commercial lot which contains a commercial use or on city property. These structures shall not be located in a required landscaped area, buffer area or required parking area. No such antenna shall be located within one hundred sixty-five feet of a residential property line.
Height Limit. Monopoles shall not project higher than twenty feet above the average building height to a maximum of sixty feet or, if there are no buildings within three hundred feet, these facilities shall not project higher than ten feet above the average tree canopy height to a maximum of sixty feet, measured from ground level.
Landscaping, Fencing and Safety. Ground surrounding monopoles shall, at minimum, be landscaped a minimum of two square feet per linear foot of the height of the pole. If there are no buildings immediately adjacent to the monopole and equipment facilities, all monopoles and equipment facilities shall be surrounded by dense tree growth to screen views of the facility in all directions. These trees may be existing on the subject property or planted on subject property. The planning commission may require additional landscaping or fencing as part of the site plan approval and conditional use process. The climbing pegs shall be removed from the lower twenty feet of the monopole.
The applicant shall re-submit each telecommunication facility which has been granted a technical necessity exception/conditional use for review each year for seven years from the date of final approval as established by the city council as part of the conditional use approval process. At the time of this review, the applicant shall provide information to show that the telecommunications facility is still necessary at the approved location, employs the most current available technological advances and that it has been in compliance with all the requirements established by this ordinance and the city council.
Additional Conditional Use Requirements. In addition to conditional use standards outlined herein, the following factors shall be considered by the planning commission and/or city council:
Compatibility of the proposed structure with the height and mass of existing buildings and utility structures;
Whether co-location of the antenna on other existing structures in the same vicinity such as other towers, buildings, water towers, utility poles, athletic field lights, parking lot lights, etc., is possible without significantly impacting antenna transmission or reception;
The location of the antenna in relation to existing vegetation, topography and buildings to obtain the best visual screening;
Whether the spacing between monopoles creates quantifiable detrimental impacts to adjoining properties;
The planning commission and/or city council may reduce the required setback from a residential zone if practical difficulties are demonstrated by the applicant (i.e., city park location, public buildings etc.) or upon detailed demonstration by the applicant that the proposed facility can be effectively screened from the view of nearby sensitive land uses; provided, that no pole may be permitted closer than one and one-half times the height of the pole to any residential dwelling;
All antenna locations shall provide assurance that the installation complies with all applicable standards and regulations, including, but not limited to Uniform Building Code, National Electric Codes, Federal Communication Commission, Federal Aviation Administration, and Environmental Agency as well as all other city ordinances. Each application for a permit to build a communications tower shall be certified by a licensed professional engineer that the design meets all standards herein. No communication facility shall encroach upon or block vehicular or pedestrian access at any time. Climbing pegs or access ladders shall be removed from the lower twenty feet regardless of location. Antennas shall be mounted with such standards that the structure can easily withstand wind force up to eighty miles per hour.
Height Limit. In all cases, the maximum height limit for single user monopoles is sixty feet. In all cases, the maximum height limit for multiple user monopoles is eighty feet. Each pole location requires a separate technical exception/conditional use permit.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.036 Equipment Facilities
All equipment facilities shall be (1) located in an existing building (2) buried or (3) designed whereby the incorporation of stealth design technology or other screening is utilized that readily conceals the appearance of the equipment facility. All power lines on the lot leading to the telecommunication facility shall be underground. If the applicant can not utilize stealth technology and bury the power lines for the proposed antenna then the applicant shall be required to apply for a technical exception/conditional use permit. The city council shall require the applicant to place the equipment facility underground, within an existing building or within a brick or stone shelter. If an existing building is within the reasonable vicinity of the proposed antenna and the equipment will not fit within the existing building then the council shall require the applicant to modify the existing building, using the same materials and architecture, to provide room for the equipment however any modification shall meet all existing zoning ordinances and building codes. In addition the city council may require the telecommunications facility area to be fenced with a six foot vinyl coated chain-link fence or other fencing such as masonry, concrete, or wrought iron. A higher quality fence shall be required if it is determined by the city council that a higher quality fence is more consistent with any adjacent developed property or existing fencing. In addition the city council shall require landscaping that shall conceal a minimum of fifty percent of the exterior fence to screen the equipment facility while allowing equal visibility for security. Accessory buildings to antenna structures must comply with the required setback, height and landscaping requirements of the zoning in which they are located. There shall be no climbing pegs located on the lower twenty feet of the monopole. All power lines on the lot leading to the accessory building(s) and antenna structure shall be underground.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.038 Historic Sites
Any telecommunications facility proposed for a location within a historic or on a landmark site is not permitted.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.040 Antennas Not Permitted
The following telecommunications facilities are not allowed in any zone:

Lattice towers.
Whip antennas on wall-mounted support structures.
Top hat antennas.
Any telecommunications facility not specifically listed in the permitted use subsection or not in compliance with the requirements for a technical necessity exception/conditional use.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.042 Business License Requirement
Separate Use. Each separate pole or tower, and each separate antenna assembly on a given pole or tower shall be considered as a separate use, and an annual business license shall be required for each such facility.
Revocation of Business License. Failure to comply with any of the requirements of this chapter, any applicable chapter of this city, or any state or federal law or regulation, constitutes grounds to revoke the business license of the facility and the wireless antenna.
Property Owner. The owner of property where a telecommunication antenna is located on shall obtain a business license for the operation and lease of a telecommunication facility prior to submitting a building permit for the construction of that wireless facility or antenna.
HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)

13.44.044 Non-Maintained Or Abandoned Facilities
The community development director may require each non-maintained or abandoned telecommunication facility to be removed when such a telecommunications facility has not been repaired or put into use by the owner, person having control or person receiving benefit of such structure within thirty calendar days after notice of non-maintenance or abandonment is given to the owner, person having control or person receiving the benefit of such structure. The city may require a cash or surety bond to guarantee removal of the telecommunications facility to be submitted prior to final site plan approval or issuance of a building permit. The bond amount shall be determined upon review by city staff. If the structure upon which the antenna is placed, including but not limited to utility pole, water tank, light pole or building is no longer used or is proposed by the owner or operator of that structure to be removed or replaced, the antenna must be removed within ninety calendar days after notice from the city. Any replacement telecommunication facility, if necessary, is required to comply with the requirements herein or any subsequent amendment hereto. Failure to properly obtain or maintain the required business license for a period of six months or more, shall be considered an abandonment of the facility.

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.046 Building Permits
Prior to the construction of any telecommunications facility, the applicant shall obtain the proper building permits, road cut permits, and other permits as required by the Highland City Municipal Code and Development Code (Land Use Ordinance).

HMC (Ord. No. 2007-4, 3-20-2007)
13.44.048 Wireless Telecommunications Facilities Illustrations
The illustrations indicated in Addendum A are referred to in this chapter. They have been created and attached to this code to demonstrate graphically the intent of the ordinance.

13.48.010 Definitions
As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall be defined as set out in this section unless the context clearly requires otherwise:

"Burial" means the opening and closing of a grave for the interment of deceased humans.

"Burial right" means the right to be buried in the city cemetery, subject to the rules and regulations of the cemetery, present and future.

"Cemetery" means any cemetery owned or maintained by the city for the purpose of receiving the remains of deceased humans.

"City" means the City of Highland.

"Lot" means a grave site in the cemetery owned by the city.

"Lot owner or purchaser" and "grave owner or purchaser" means the owner or purchaser of a burial right or privileges evidenced by a burial right certificate.

"Nonresident" means any person(s) not a resident.

"Resident" means any person who has his principal place of residence within the city and who has a present intention to continue residency within the city permanently or indefinitely. For purposes of this definition under this chapter, any person who previously qualified as a resident of Highland, prior to the establishment and availability of a burial right in Highland, will be eligible to purchase a burial right at resident prices until January 1, 2002.

The following rules shall be used to assist in determining the "place of residence" of any person:
The residence of a person is the place in which his habitation is fixed and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning.
A person shall not be held to have gained or lost a residence solely by reason of his presence or absence while employed in the service of the United States or of the State of Utah, or while a student at any institution of learning, or while incarcerated in prison or jail, or while residing upon any Indian or military reservation, or while serving a mission for his church.
A person shall not be considered to have lost his residence who leaves his home to go into a foreign country or into another state or precinct within this state for temporary purposes merely with the intention of returning.
A person shall not be considered to have gained a residence in any other city into which he comes merely for temporary purposes without intention of making such city his home.
If a person removes to another city or location with the intention of making it his principal place of residence, he loses his residence in this city.
If a person removes to another city of location with the intention of remaining there for an indefinite time as a place of permanent residence, he loses his residence in this city notwithstanding he entertains an intention of returning at some future period.
The place where a person's family resides is presumed to be his place of residence, but any person who takes up or continues his abode with the intention of remaining at a place other than where his family resides must be regarded as a resident where he so abides.
A change of residence can only be made by the act of removal joined with the intent to remain in another place. There can only be one residence. A residence cannot be lost until another is gained.
HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))

13.48.020 Name Established
The cemetery of the city shall be known and designated as the "Highland City Cemetery."

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.030 Cemeteries Covered
All cemeteries owned or maintained by the city, or which may hereafter be acquired by the city, wherever situated, are hereby declared subject to the provisions of this chapter.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.040 Penalty
Any person who violates any part of this chapter is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.050 Hours
It is unlawful for any person other than city employees performing their duties to be in the cemetery between the hours of eleven p.m. and six a.m. of the following day.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.060 Only Humans To Be Buried
There shall be no burial of anything other than the remains of human bodies in cemetery.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.070 Vaults Required
It is unlawful for any person to be buried in the cemetery unless: (a) the casket is placed in a vault made of concrete, steel or their equivalent and (b) the vault is approved by the city. No wood or fiberglass shall be used in the construction of any part of any vault. Exceptions to the provisions of this section may be granted for infant or cremation burials only. In such instances of exceptions, the design and construction of the burial vault shall be approved by the city.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.080 Burial Rights And Ownership
All property including lots, plots and grave sites within the cemetery is owned by the city. The city reserves the right of easement over and across any burial lot or plot for grass repairs, installation or maintenance of water lines, and for the opening and closing of adjacent graves.

Purchase of Burial Right. Upon purchase of a burial lot the purchaser acquires a burial right.
Permit. Burial shall not take place unless a proper burial permit has been issued by the city. Burial shall not begin any sooner than twenty-four hours after the issuance of a burial permit. Weekends and holidays shall not be considered in determining the twenty-four-hour period. Under no circumstances will the city assume responsibility for errors in opening graves when orders are given by telephone. No exhumations shall be permitted without permission of the sexton. All exhumations must comply with applicable state law.
Taxes. A burial right conveyed shall be exempt from taxation.
Descent and Inheritance of Rights. A burial right in the cemetery is conveyed to the person or persons named therein and their heirs forever. All legal heirs are presumed to have legal right to the rights of burial, unless heirship to the contrary has been determined by a court of probate after named parties in the original burial right certificate are deceased.
Use of Lot. No person, except the owner of the burial right on a lot, shall be buried on that lot, unless a form provided by the city has been signed by the owner or legal heirs to those rights, giving permission for someone else to be buried on that lot.
Double Depth Burials. Only upon the request of the owner, double depth burial may be allowed in locations in the cemetery as determined by the city, consistent with the water table, ground and other relevant conditions for double depth burials. Double depth burials require separate vaults, and are subject to additional opening and closing fees.
Burials per Grave. Only one burial shall be allowed per grave space, except for double depth burials. Combined parent-infant may be authorized by the sexton if, in the sexton's judgment, conditions at the lot allow for such combined burial.
Non-Refundable One Year Option to Reserve Lot(s).  The Sexton or Registrar may, pursuant to contract, reserve such other lots as requested by the family and for which an amount equal to ten percent (10%) of the current approved fee schedule is tendered to and received by the sexton or registrar at the time the initial lots are purchased. Such additional payment and contact shall constitute an option and shall be recorded and noted upon the cemetery plats of the city. The family shall then have the exclusive right to tender in one lump sum the full purchase price (minus a credit for the option price payment which shall be credited thereto) required on such other lots, at the price in effect on the date such option was created, anytime within the following twelve (12) months. If such option is not exercised, the option payment shall be retained by the city for the care and maintenance of the cemetery grounds in its perpetual care fund. If such option is exercised, a certificate of burial rights to such lots shall be issued and recorded upon payment of the full purchase price and perpetual care fees.
HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))

HISTORY
Amended by Ord. O-2017-06 on 3/7/2017
13.48.090 Applicability Of Traffic Regulations
The provisions of the city traffic ordinances relative to the operation of vehicles and conduct of pedestrians shall apply in the cemetery. The speed limit in the cemetery shall be ten miles per hour.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.100 Funeral Processions
Funerals processions shall proceed to the cemetery under the direction of the funeral director. Within the cemetery, city employees may direct traffic for the purposes of maintaining traffic flow and for the proper parking of vehicles. All vehicles in the cemetery shall be driven in a careful, quiet and orderly manner.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.110 Right To Maintain
The city reserves the right to enter upon any lot to perform all work necessary for the maintenance of the cemetery. The city is responsible for the total maintenance of the cemetery. The city shall not be responsible for the repair or replacement of markers or memorial structures of any nature, unless the city caused the damage or destruction to the marker or memorial structure. The city retains the right to remove any marker which it determines to be unsightly or dangerous markers.

Plantings. No planting shall be allowed in the cemetery by private individuals, except for those plantings which have prior approval in writing by the city. In determining whether to allow private planting, the city shall consider whether the planting is in harmony with the cemetery landscape and if the planting will interfere with the cemetery maintenance and safety. Any object, flower, shrub or decoration not in compliance with this chapter may be removed immediately by the city.
Grave Decorations. All floral arrangements shall be allowed for five days, after which they may be removed by the city. Glass containers shall not be allowed. Any objects such as wires, sticks, pegs, or irons driven into the ground shall not be permitted.
Artificial Flowers. Artificial flowers, windmills, toys, rocks, wrought iron, or other such similar ornamentation are allowed only in the cemetery on or within the borders of the marker, provided they do not interfere with the maintenance of the cemetery.
HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))

13.48.120 Private Improvements Prohibited; Survey And Marking Of Lots
It is unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any structure, fence, corner post, coping or hedge of any kind upon any lot, street, or driveway in the cemetery, or grade the ground or land thereof. The city shall, upon request, furnish the boundary lines of lots. The city shall prohibit landmarks and any grading that might destroy or interfere with the general slope of the land. It is unlawful for any person to plant shrubs, trees, lawns, flowers etc., place decorative stones, place monuments or markers, or other structures upon any lot in the cemetery without approval and direction from the city.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.130 Grave Markers
Headstones are personal property. All monuments within the cemetery are the property of burial right owners, their heirs, or the responsible party. All care and upkeep of the monuments are the responsibility of the owner and heirs. The city shall not be responsible for the repair or replacement of markers, including damage caused by nature or vandalism, unless the city caused the damage or destruction to the marker.

Size. A headstone and the concrete border must fit within the boundary of the grave or graves. All headstones, markers or monuments shall have a stone or cement base, level with the ground, extending outward from the perimeter of the base of the headstone or marker and shall be a minimum of four inches (4") on all sides, with a minimum thickness of four inches (4"). Headstones will be of stone, concrete or a non-corroding durable composition.
For a single headstone, marker or monument, the concrete base shall not exceed forty-two inches (42") in length (side to side). The concrete base shall not exceed twenty five-inches (25") in width (top to bottom).
For a double headstone, marker or monument, the concrete base shall not exceed eight-four inches (84") in length (side to side). The concrete base shall not exceed twenty five-inches (25") in width (top to bottom).
Type and Placement. Upright headstones shall be allowed in the cemetery. All headstones, markers and monuments shall be placed at the head of the grave. Exceptions to this shall apply only in the Veteran's section where one additional headstone, supplied by the Veteran's Administration, may be placed at the foot of the grave.
Other Markers. There shall be no markers, monuments or structures placed upon any lot other than those provided for in this chapter.
Re-placement of Markers. Any headstone, marker or monument that impedes the opening or closing of any burial plot will be removed and replaced at the owner's expense.
HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part); Ord. No. 2014-11, 12-2-2014)

HISTORY
Amended by Ord. O-2014-11 on 12/2/2014
13.48.140 Duties Of The City; Sexton's Duties
Burials. The city shall prepare a grave for burial upon request and after a burial permit has been issued by the city. The city shall provide supervision for every interment.
Maintenance. The city shall have the responsibility to reasonably maintain the cemetery and provide the basic services necessary for the operation of the cemetery, including water, electricity, equipment and labor.
Sexton's Duties. The city sexton shall possess such supervisory and administrative powers, duties, and responsibilities relating to city cemeteries as are not repugnant to law or contrary to any specific direction or limitation set forth by the Highland City Council, including, but not limited to, the following:
Supervising the operations and maintenance of the cemetery grounds and improving such grounds under the direction of the city council;
Recommending to the city council such additional rules and regulations as may be required for the proper and efficient operation, maintenance, use and protection of the city cemeteries;
Subdividing all city cemeteries into sections and lots, and maintaining a plat of the cemetery grounds showing the location;
Maintaining an accurate, indexed record of the present ownership or use of all burial lots in all city cemeteries. Such record shall indicate the identity of the purchaser;
Preventing any city cemetery from being used beyond its capacity, as established by the city council;
Preventing the trespass of animals not confined at all times within a vehicle and of minors not employed by the city and not accompanied by an adult; enforcing traffic regulations within city cemeteries in cooperation with the city police; reporting as well as prevention, to the extent practicable, the vandalism of cemetery property;
Opening and closing or causing to be opened or closed all graves required for the burial of the dead in city cemeteries;
Interring or permitting the interment of the remains of the dead only if such interment is to be made by a licensed funeral director or by a person in possession of a burial-transit permit as required by Section 26-2-17, Utah Code Annotated, and all other state and local laws and regulations;
Complying with the procedures mandated by Sections 26-2-17 and 26-4-12, Utah Code Annotated, and all other state and local laws and regulations;
Keeping current a true and complete record of all interments made in city cemeteries, setting forth the name of the decedent, place of death, the date of burial, and the name and address of the funeral director or other person making the interment. Such record shall be prepared and maintained at the expense of the city and shall be open to public inspection;
Preparing and sending a list of interments, made in city cemeteries each month, in the manner and to the stated officer designated in Section 26-2-18(3), Utah Code Annotated, and other applicable law;
Collecting in advance such charges and fees relating to city cemeteries as the city council may set by resolution;
Selling burial rights and collecting all sums arising from such sales, to include the purchase price of the burial rights and the fees established by resolution of the city council;
Removing or causing to be removed, without notice, floral arrangements, displays, or other items left on any greave, as deemed necessary to the appearance or maintenance of city cemeteries;
Directing parking, standing, or movement of vehicles through city cemeteries;
Performing such other duties in relation to the cemetery as may be required;
The sexton shall file and cause to be filed in the office of the Utah County Recorder an accurate plat of all city cemeteries, which shall clearly show the section of burial lots for which burial rights have been conveyed, the names of the persons owning such burial rights, and the sections of burial lots for which no burial rights have been conveyed. The city sexton shall periodically update its filings with the county recorder to reflect changes in the foregoing information and shall, prior to offering for sale any burial rights in any additions of land to a city cemetery, record a plat for the addition to the cemetery;
The city sexton shall furnish every purchaser of burial rights in a city cemetery with a certificate of burial rights, properly executed, in form sufficient to permit filing and recording by the county recorder upon payment of the purchase price and all fees required by the city. All such certificates shall state that the holder thereof has not acquired any title or interest in real property, but only holds a right to burial. Each certificate shall be signed by the mayor and attested to by the city recorder and shall constitute the sole evidence of the purchaser's interest. A certified copy of such certificate shall remain on file at the office of the city sexton;
On the first days of January and July of each year, the city sexton shall file with the Utah County Recorder a transcript, duly certified by the city sexton, of any and all burial rights, certificates of sale, or evidences of burial rights issued by the city sexton during the preceding six months;
The city sexton shall attend to every interment in the city cemeteries in person or by a competent deputy;
All receipts and cash received by the city sexton in connection with the sexton's duties at city cemeteries shall be deposited with the city treasurer, for which deposits the sexton shall take a receipt and retain the same on file in the sexton's office for a period of two years;
The city sexton and employees or other persons assigned to work at a city cemetery shall not, either directly or indirectly, knowingly act or serve as agents, employees, or salesperson for: (a) any person or company furnishing materials used at city cemetery; (b) any mortuary, funeral home, or similar establishment; or (c) any person or company selling grave markers or monuments. The city sexton and employees or other persons assigned to work at a city cemetery shall not be interested in any manner in any monument, vault, casket manufacturing, or related business, and shall not in any manner receive any profits or rewards growing out of the sale or placement of any monuments, caskets, vaults or markers. Each violation of this section is a class C misdemeanor;
The city sexton shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by the resolution of the city council.
HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))

13.48.150 Registration Of Burials And Disinterments
The city administrator shall designate a registrar of burials for the city. The registrar may, but is not required, to also serve as the sexton. Before burying any dead in the cemetery, or before disinterring for transportation beyond the corporate limits of the city the body of any person who has been buried therein, the relatives or other persons having charge of the body shall be required to furnish in writing to the registrar a statement of death, which shall be recorded in a record kept for that purpose by the registrar. The statement shall include the name of the decedent, the place of death, the date of burial and the name and address of the funeral director or other person requesting the interment. These records shall be open to public inspection.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.160 Burials Outside Cemeteries
It is unlawful to bury the body of any person within the city, except at sites designated and approved as cemeteries by the city.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.170 Burial Of Indigents
A portion of the cemetery may be designated for the burial of indigents. Whenever it is determined by the city council that any resident of Highland who has died, who does not have funds or an estate sufficient to pay the cost of a burial right and interment in the cemetery, and whose nearest relative or representative desires to have the body of such deceased interred in the cemetery, the city council may grant a burial right and interment for such deceased person at no cost to such person.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.180 Infant Burial Plot
A portion of the cemetery may be reserved for the burial of infants. For purposes of this chapter, infants shall be defined as humans under the age of one year.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.190 Animals Prohibited
No animal shall be allowed in the cemetery except in the confines of a vehicle. Animals include, without limitation, horses, dogs, cats.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.200 Operating Hours; Holiday Funerals
Cemetery operating hours are Monday through Friday eight a.m. to four p.m. Overtime fees will be charged for other hours such as Saturdays, Sundays or holidays observed by Highland City.
Interments or disinterments in the cemetery shall not be allowed on Christmas Day or on Memorial Day weekend beginning at twelve noon on Saturday through Memorial Day.
HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))

13.48.210 Fees
Residency. The city shall assess nonresidents a higher fee than residents for the purchase of a burial right and the cost of interment. Residency status shall be determined as of the date of purchase of the burial right.
Payment. All prices, fees and charges pertaining to the cemetery shall be established by resolution of the city council. No burial, opening, closing or interment, shall take place until all appropriate fees have been timely paid to the registrar.
HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))

13.48.220 Resale Restricted
No person who owns any burial right or lots shall sell such burial right or lots to any buyer except the city. The city agrees to repurchase any unused burial right for the present value of such burial right.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.230 Damaged Property
It is unlawful for any person to damage, injure or deface any monument, tree, shrub, lawn, building, structure or facility, on the grounds of the cemetery. The city shall not be responsible or liable for flowers or other personal property left at the cemetery.

HMC (Ord. 1998-17 (part))
13.48.240 Reversion Of Burial Right To City
A burial right that has been unused, or have no written notices of claim or interest on, for more than sixty years will be reclaimed by the cemetery. Every effort, practically and legally, will first be made to find the owner or legal heirs before the burial lot is reverted.
